question: Question 1 If the Fore Bearing of the lines [latex]AB[/latex] and [latex]BC[/latex] are [latex]60^\circ[/latex] and [latex]122^\circ[/latex], respectively, then the interior angle [latex]\angle ABC[/latex] (in degrees) is ______ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: To find the interior angle [latex]\angle ABC[/latex], we use the difference between: The Back Bearing of line [latex]AB[/latex], and The Fore Bearing of line [latex]BC[/latex] Step 1: Calculate Back Bearing of AB [latex] \text{FB of } AB = 60^\circ [/latex] [latex] \text{BB of } AB = 60^\circ + 180^\circ = 240^\circ [/latex] Step 2: Given Fore Bearing of BC [latex] \text{FB of } BC = 122^\circ [/latex] Step 3: Interior Angle at Point B [latex] \angle ABC = BB_{AB} - FB_{BC} = 240^\circ - 122^\circ = \boxed{118^\circ} [/latex]

question:
Question 2 On a two-lane highway, a horizontal curve of radius [latex]300\ \text{m}[/latex] is provided.
The design speed is [latex]80\ \text{km/h}[/latex]. If the longest wheelbase of the vehicle expected on this highway is [latex]7\ \text{m}[/latex], then the extra widening required (in m) is ______ (round off to two decimal places).
solution: As per IRC, extra widening on a horizontal curve is given by the formula: [latex]W_e = W_m + W_{ph}[/latex] Where: [latex]W_m = \text{mechanical widening} = \frac{n l^2}{2R}[/latex] [latex]W_{ph} = \text{psychological widening} = \frac{v}{9.5 \sqrt{R}}[/latex] Given: [latex]n = 2,\ l = 7\ \text{m},\ R = 300\ \text{m},\ v = 80\ \text{km/h}[/latex] Step 1: Mechanical Widening [latex]W_m = \frac{2 \times 7^2}{2 \times 300} = \frac{98}{600} = 0.1633\ \text{m}[/latex] Step 2: Psychological Widening [latex]\sqrt{R} = \sqrt{300} \approx 17.32[/latex] [latex]W_{ph} = \frac{80}{9.5 \times 17.32} = \frac{80}{164.54} \approx 0.4863\ \text{m}[/latex] Step 3: Total Extra Widening [latex]W_e = 0.1633 + 0.4863 = \boxed{0.65\ \text{m}}[/latex]

question: Question 3 The free flow speed of a highway is 100 km/h and its capacity is 4000 vehicle/h. Assume speed-density relation is linear. For a traffic volume of 2000 vehicle/h, choose all the possible speeds (in km/h) from the options given below (round off to two decimal places).
solution: Given: Free flow speed [latex] V_f = 100 \text{ km/h} [/latex] Capacity [latex] Q_{\text{max}} = 4000 \text{ veh/h} [/latex] Flow [latex] Q = 2000 \text{ veh/h} [/latex] In a linear speed-density relationship: [latex] Q = k \cdot v [/latex] Where: [latex] k [/latex] is the density [latex] v [/latex] is the speed Maximum flow (capacity) occurs at: [latex] k = k_j / 2 \quad \text{and} \quad v = V_f / 2 [/latex] So at capacity: [latex] Q_{\text{max}} = (k_j/2)(V_f/2) = \frac{k_j V_f}{4} [/latex] Solving for [latex] k_j [/latex]: [latex] k_j = \frac{4 Q_{\text{max}}}{V_f} = \frac{4 \cdot 4000}{100} = 160 \text{ veh/km} [/latex] Now for given flow [latex] Q = 2000 [/latex]: Let [latex] v [/latex] be the possible speed: [latex] Q = k \cdot v \Rightarrow 2000 = k \cdot v \Rightarrow k = \frac{2000}{v} [/latex] From linear speed-density relation: [latex] v = V_f \left(1 - \frac{k}{k_j}\right) = 100 \left(1 - \frac{2000/v}{160}\right) [/latex] [latex] v = 100 \left(1 - \frac{2000}{160v}\right) [/latex] Multiply both sides by [latex] 160v [/latex]: [latex] 160v^2 = 16000v - 2000000 [/latex] [latex] v^2 - 100v + 12500 = 0 [/latex] Solving this quadratic: [latex] v = \frac{100 \pm \sqrt{100^2 - 4 \cdot 1 \cdot 12500}}{2} = \frac{100 \pm \sqrt{10000 - 50000}}{2} = \frac{100 \pm \sqrt{-40000}}{2} [/latex] Oops! That's an error! Let's fix it: Correct equation: Go back to: [latex] v = 100 \left(1 - \frac{2000}{160v} \right) [/latex] [latex] v = 100 - \frac{200000}{160v} [/latex] Multiply both sides by [latex] v [/latex]: [latex] v^2 = 100v - \frac{200000}{160} = 100v - 1250 [/latex] So: [latex] v^2 - 100v + 1250 = 0 [/latex] Now solving: [latex] v = \frac{100 \pm \sqrt{100^2 - 4 \cdot 1 \cdot 1250}}{2} = \frac{100 \pm \sqrt{10000 - 5000}}{2} = \frac{100 \pm \sqrt{5000}}{2} [/latex] [latex] \sqrt{5000} \approx 70.71 [/latex] [latex] v = \frac{100 \pm 70.71}{2} [/latex] [latex] v_1 = \frac{100 + 70.71}{2} = 85.36 \text{ km/h} [/latex] [latex] v_2 = \frac{100 - 70.71}{2} = 14.64 \text{ km/h} [/latex] So, possible speeds are: [latex] \boxed{85.36 \text{ km/h},\ 14.64 \text{ km/h}} [/latex] Correct options: (A) and (C)

question:
Question 4 Match the following in Column I with Column II. [latex]\begin{array}{|c|l|c|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Column I} & & \textbf{Column II} & \\
\hline
(1) & \text{Vehicle Damage Factor}       & A. & \text{Stability of subgrade soil} \\
(2) & \text{Passenger Car Unit}          & B. & \text{Capacity of a roadway} \\
(3) & \text{Perception Reaction Time}    & C. & \text{Design rigid pavement} \\
(4) & \text{California Bearing Ratio}    & D. & \text{Design flexible pavement} \\
      &                                            & E. & \text{Stopping sight distance} \\
\hline
\end{array}[/latex]
solution: Vehicle Damage Factor (VDF) -> (D) Design flexible pavement VDF is used to account for the damage caused by different vehicles in the design of flexible pavements. Passenger Car Unit (PCU)  -> (B) Capacity of a roadway PCU is used to convert different vehicles to an equivalent number of passenger cars, which is crucial in estimating roadway capacity. Perception Reaction Time -> (E) Stopping sight distance This is the time taken by a driver to perceive and react to a situation, used in calculating stopping sight distance. California Bearing Ratio (CBR)  -> (A) Stability of subgrade soil CBR is a penetration test for evaluating the strength of subgrade soil.

question: Question 5 Which of the following statements is/are INCORRECT?
solution: (A) INCORRECT: In warm climates, bitumen with a higher softening point is preferred to prevent rutting and bleeding. (B) CORRECT: Viscosity indeed affects mixing and compaction of bituminous mixes. (C) CORRECT: Optimum bitumen content is determined by maintaining 3%-5% air voids. (D) CORRECT: The Solubility Test checks purity by measuring insoluble impurities. Hence, the incorrect statement is (A).

options.A: Bitumen having lower softening point is preferred in warm climate regions.
options.B: The viscosity of bitumen influences the mixing and compaction of bituminous mix.
options.C: The air voids in the range of 3% to 5% are required to arrive at the optimum bitumen content.
options.D: The purity of bitumen can be determined using Solubility Test.

question: Question 6 The point where the road alignment changes from a tangent to a curve is known as ______
solution:
In highway geometric design terminology: The Point of Curve (PC) is the location where the tangent ends and the circular curve begins. The Point of Tangency (PT) is where the curve ends and the tangent resumes. The Point of Intersection (PI) is the point where two tangents intersect. The Point of Deflection is not a standard term in horizontal curve geometry.

Therefore, the point where the alignment changes from a tangent to a curve is: Answer: (C) Point of curve

question: Question 7 After applying the correction for elevation and temperature, the runway length is 700 m. The corrected runway length (in m) for an effective gradient of 1% is ______ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given: Corrected runway length after elevation and temperature = [latex] 700\ \text{m} [/latex] Effective gradient = [latex] 1% [/latex] As per IRC 9157 and ICAO guidelines, if the effective gradient exceeds [latex] 0.4% [/latex], then an additional correction is applied. For an effective gradient of [latex] 1% [/latex], the recommended correction is 20% of the basic length. So, the final corrected runway length is: [latex] L_{\text{final}} = 700 + 0.20 \times 700 = 700 \times 1.20 = 840\ \text{m} [/latex]

question: Question 8 The recommended minimum traffic growth rate and design period considered for structural design of flexible pavements for national highways in India as per IRC 37:2018 is ______ percentage and ______ years, respectively.
solution:
As per IRC 37:2018, the recommended minimum traffic growth rate is:
[latex] 5% [/latex] And the minimum design period for national highways is:  20 years

question:
Question 9 During determination of the bulk specific gravity of compacted bituminous 
specimen, the mass in air of the specimen is 1260 at and volume is [latex]525 \mathrm{~cm}^3[/latex]. The density of water is [latex]1.0 \mathrm{~g}/{\mathrm{k}} \mathrm{cm}^3[/latex]. The theoretical maximum specific gravity of mix is 2.510 . The percentage air voids in the compacted specimen is ________ (rounded of to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given: Mass in air, [latex]M = 1260\ \text{g}[/latex] Volume, [latex]V = 525\ \text{cm}^3[/latex] Density of water, [latex]\rho = 1.0\ \text{g/cm}^3[/latex] Theoretical maximum specific gravity, [latex]G_{mm} = 2.510[/latex] Step 1: Bulk specific gravity of specimen: [latex]G_{mb} = \frac{M}{V \cdot \rho} = \frac{1260}{525 \cdot 1} = 2.4[/latex] Step 2: Air voids percentage: [latex]\text{Air Voids} (%) = \left( \frac{G_{mm} - G_{mb}}{G_{mm}} \right) \times 100[/latex] [latex]= \left( \frac{2.510 - 2.4}{2.510} \right) \times 100 = \left( \frac{0.11}{2.510} \right) \times 100 = 4.38%[/latex]

Question 10 A one-way, single lane road has traffic that consists of [latex]30 \%[/latex] trucks and [latex]70 \%[/latex] cars. The speed of trucks (in kmh) is a uniform random variable on the interval ( 30,60 ), and the speed of cars (in kmh) is a unform random variable on the interval (40,804. The speed limit on the road is 50 kmh . The percentage of vehicles that exceed the speed limit is _________
 (rounded off to 1 decimal place). Nota: [latex]X[/latex] is a uniform random variable on the interval ( [latex]\alpha , \beta[/latex]), if Its probability density function is given by [latex]
f(x)= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{\beta-\alpha} & \alpha < x <\beta \\ \alpha & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
[/latex]

Question 11 The speed-density relation on a one-way, single lane road is shown in the figure, where speed [latex]u[/latex] is in [latex]\mathrm{km} /[/latex] hour and density [latex]k[/latex] is in vehicles/km. The maximum flow (in vehicles/hour) on this road is
solution: The linear speed-density relationship can be written as: [latex] u = \text{slope} \cdot (k - 10) + 90 [/latex] [latex] \text{slope} = \frac{0 - 90}{100 - 10} = \frac{-90}{90} = -1 [/latex] So, [latex] u = -1(k - 10) + 90 = -k + 100 [/latex] Flow [latex]q[/latex] is given by: [latex] q = u \cdot k = (100 - k) \cdot k = 100k - k^2 [/latex] To find maximum flow: Differentiate [latex]q[/latex] with respect to [latex]k[/latex]: [latex] \frac{dq}{dk} = 100 - 2k [/latex] Set [latex] \frac{dq}{dk} = 0 [/latex]: [latex] 100 - 2k = 0 \Rightarrow k = 50\ \text{veh/km} [/latex] Substitute back to find speed [latex]u[/latex]: [latex] u = 100 - 50 = 50\ \text{km/h} [/latex] Now calculate flow: [latex] q_{\text{max}} = u \cdot k = 50 \cdot 50 = 2500\ \text{veh/hr} [/latex]

question: Question 12 Road [latex]A[/latex] and Road [latex]B[/latex] are joined by a circular horizontal curve of radius 200 m as shown in the figure. Road [latex]A[/latex] and Road [latex]B[/latex] are tangential to the curve at the points [latex]C[/latex] and [latex]D[/latex], respectively. Had the curve not been there, straight roads [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]B[/latex] would have met at the point [latex]E[/latex]. The distance from [latex]C[/latex] to [latex]E[/latex] is 92 m . The value of angle [latex]\theta[/latex] (in degrees) is ________ (rounded off to 1 decimal place). Note: The value of angle is to be calculated only from the consideration of Euclidean geometry and the data given in the problem.
solution: Given: [latex] R = 200 , \text{m} [/latex] (radius of curve) [latex] CE = 92 , \text{m} [/latex] (distance from C to E) From geometry: [latex] CE = R \cdot \tan\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) [/latex] Substitute values: [latex] \tan\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) = \frac{92}{200} = 0.46 [/latex] [latex] \frac{\theta}{2} = \tan^{-1}(0.46) \approx 24.8^\circ [/latex] [latex] \theta = 2 \times 24.8^\circ = \boxed{49.6^\circ} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \theta = 49.6^\circ [/latex]

question: Question 14 In the context of testing bitumen, which one of the following statements is FALSE:
solution: (A) The depth of penetration of needle in the standard penetration test is measured in the units of one-tenth of millimeter. This statement is correct. The penetration value is expressed in tenths of a millimeter. (B) Softening point is measured using a ring and ball apparatus. This statement is correct. The softening point test involves a steel ball and a brass ring filled with bitumen. (C) Softening point is measured in the units of time. This statement is false. The softening point is measured in units of temperature, typically in [latex] ^\circ \text{C} [/latex]. (D) Ductility is measured in the units of length. This statement is correct. Ductility is usually measured in centimeters or millimeters.

options.A: The depth of penetration of needle in the standard penetration test is measured in the units of one-tenth of millimeter
options.B: Softening point is measured using a ring and ball apparatus
options.C: Softening point is measured in the units of time
options.D: Ductility is measured in the units of length

question: Question 15 All the vehicles that come during a particular peak hour come during a 10-minute period within this hour. The 15-minute peak hour factor for this peak hour is
solution: Given: All vehicles during the peak hour arrive within a 10-minute period. To find: 15-minute Peak Hour Factor (PHF) Formula: [latex]\text{PHF} = \frac{\text{Hourly Volume}}{4 \times \text{Peak 15-minute Volume}}[/latex] Since all vehicles arrive within a 10-minute period, they are included within the peak 15-minute period. Therefore, [latex]\text{PHF} = \frac{V}{4 \times V} = \frac{1}{4} = 0.25[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]0.25[/latex]

Design speed [latex] =80 \mathrm{kmph} [/latex] Eye height of truck drivers above the road surface [latex] =2.30 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] Height of object above the road surface for which trucks need to stop [latex] =0.35 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] Total reaction time of the truck drivers [latex] =2.0 \mathrm{~s} [/latex] Coefficient of longitudinal friction of the road [latex] =0.36 [/latex] Stopping sight distance gets compesnated on the gradient. The design length of the summit curve (in meters) to accommodate the stopping sight distance is _____ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 18 In the context of pavement material characterization, the CORRECT statement(s) is/are
solution: In a bituminous mix VMA [latex] = [/latex] Voids in mineral aggregate [latex] \mathrm{VMA}=\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{b}} \%+\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{v}} \% [/latex] where, [latex] \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{b}} \%= [/latex] Percentage volume of bitumen [latex] \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{v}} \%= [/latex] Percentage air voids Toughness is determined by aggregate impact test and hardness is determined by los angeles abrasion test. An initial concavity in CBR curve indicate errors which may occur due to following reasons and also require correction Top layer of soil too soft Top surface of soil specimen is not even The penetration plunger of the loading machine is not vertical and the bottom of plunger is not horizontal.

question: Question 28 A car is travelling at a speed of [latex] 60 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}[/latex] on a section of a National Highway having a downward gradient of [latex] 2 \%[/latex] . The driver of the car suddenly observes a stopped vehicle on the car path at a distance [latex] 130 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] ahead, and applies brake. If the brake efficiency is [latex] 60 \%[/latex] , coefficient of friction is 0.7 , driver's reaction time is [latex] 2.5 \mathrm{~s}[/latex]. and acceleration due to gravity is [latex] 9.81 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex], the distance (in meters) required by the driver to bring the car to a safe stop lies in the range
solution:
Given, [latex]
V=60 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}, t_{R}=2.5 \mathrm{sec}[/latex] Braking efficiency, [latex]\eta=60 \%[/latex] Coefficient of friction, [latex]\mu=0.7 \%[/latex] Down grace, [latex] s=2 \%[/latex] Stopping sight distance =  Lag distance + Braking distance [latex]\begin{aligned}
& =0.278 \times V \times t_{r}+\frac{V^{2}}{254(\eta f-s)} \\
& =0.278 \times 60 \times 2.5+\frac{60^{2}}{254(0.6(0.7)-0.02)} \\
& =41.7+35.4 \\
& =77.1 \mathrm{~m}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 The figure presents the time-space diagram for when the traffic on a highway is suddenly stopped for a certain time and then released. Which of the following statements are true?
solution: Any vertical line drawn in the graph which cuts arrow lines give positions of vehicles in different regions at a particular time. Slope of a line in a region represents speed of vehicles in that particular region. From the Plot : 1. Distance between position of vehicles in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than that in region [latex]R \Rightarrow[/latex] Density in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than that in region ' [latex]R[/latex] '. 2. Slope of lines in region ' [latex]Q[/latex] ' [latex]=0 \Rightarrow[/latex] Speed of vehicles in region ' [latex]\mathrm{Q}[/latex] ' is zero. 3. Slope of lines in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than in region ' [latex]R[/latex] ' [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] speed of vehicles in region ' [latex]P[/latex] ' is greater than in region ' [latex]R[/latex] '. 4. Since vehicles in region ' [latex]Q[/latex] ' are stationary, flow or volume in region ' [latex]Q[/latex] ' is zero and hence lower than in region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex] or region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex]. And density in region ' [latex]\mathrm{Q}[/latex] ' is higher than in region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex] or region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex]. 5. Boundary between region ' [latex]P[/latex] and ' [latex]R[/latex] ' represents 'forward moving slope wave' means slope is positive. i.e. [latex]\quad[/latex] slope [latex]=\frac{q_{R}-q_{P}}{K_{R}-K_{P}} \gt 0[/latex] q - Flow [latex]\mathrm{K}[/latex] - Density. Since [latex]\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{R}} \gt \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{P}}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{R}}[/latex] should be greater than [latex]\mathrm{q}_{\mathrm{P}}[/latex]. [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Volume/flow in region ' [latex]R[/latex] ' is higher than in Region 'P'.

options.A: Speed is higher in Region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex] than in Region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex]
options.B: Volume is lower in Region [latex]Q[/latex] than in Region [latex]P[/latex]
options.C: Volume is higher in Region [latex]\mathrm{R}[/latex] than in Region [latex]\mathrm{P}[/latex]

question: Question 31 As per the Indian Roads Congress guidelines (IRC 86: 2018), extra widening depends on which of the following parameters?
solution: As per IRC [latex]86: 2018[/latex] Clause 8.6 Widening of Carriageway on Curves: At sharp horizontal curves, it is necessary to widen the carriageway to provide for safe passage of vehicles. The widening required has two components: (i) mechanical widening to components for the extra width occupied by a vehicle on the curve due to tracking of the rare wheels, and (ii) psychological widening to permit easy crossing of vehicles since vehicles in a lane tend to wander more on a curve than on a straight reach. On two-lane or wider roads, it is necessary that both the above components should be fully catered for so that the lateral clearance between vehicles of curves is maintained equal to the clearance available on straight. Position of single-lane roads however is somewhat different. Since during crossing maneuvers outer wheels of vehicles have in any case to use the shoulder whether on the straight or on the curve. It is, therefore sufficient on single lane roads if only the mechanical component of widening is taken into account. Based on the above considerations, the extra width of carriageway to be provided at horizontal curves on single and two-lane roads is given in Table For multi-lane roads, the pavement widening may be calculated by adding half the widening for two-lane roads to each lane. Table : Extra width of Pavement at Horizontal Curves

Question 36 The lane configuration with lane volumes in vehicles per hour of a four-arm
signalized intersection is shown in the figure. There are only two phases: the first
phase is for the East-West and the West-East through movements, and the second
phase is for the North-South and the South-North through movements. There are
no turning movements. Assume that the saturation flow is 1800 vehicles per hour
per lane for each lane and the total lost time for the first and the second phases
together is 9 seconds. The optimum cycle length (in seconds), as per the Webster's method, is
____________. (round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
From figure [latex]\begin{aligned}
y_{N-S}&=\left [ \frac{360}{1800},\frac{396}{1800} \right ]_{max}\\
&=0.22\\
y_{E-W}&=\left [ \frac{504+504}{2 \times 18},\frac{440}{1800} ,\frac{460}{1800}\right ]_{max}\\
&=0.28\\
&\text{Optimum cycle length}\\
&=\frac{1.5L+5}{1-y}\\
&=\frac{1.5 \times 9+5}{1-(y_{N-S}+y_{E-W})}\\
&=\frac{1.5 \times 9+5}{1-(0.22+0.28)}\\
C_o&=37secs.
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 37 Assuming that traffic on a highway obeys the Greenshields model, the speed of
a shockwave between two traffic streams (P) and (Q) as shown in the schematic
is _______ kmph. (in integer)
solution:
[latex] \text{Speed of shock wave}=\frac{\text{Change in flow}}{\text{Change in density}}[/latex] [latex]\text{Flow}=\text{Speed} \times \text{Density} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
Density&=\frac{Flow}{speed}\\
&=\frac{q_Q-q_P}{\frac{q_Q}{V_Q}-\frac{q_P}{V_P}}\\
 &=\frac{1800-1200}{\frac{1800}{30}-\frac{1200}{60}}\\
&=\frac{600}{60-20}\\
&=15Kmph
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 38 A parabolic vertical crest curve connects two road segments with grades +1.0% and -2.0%. If a 200 m stopping sight distance is needed for a driver at a height of 1.2 m to avoid an obstacle of height 0.15 m, then the minimum curve length
should be ______ m. (round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
Given that, [latex] n_1=+1%[/latex] and [latex] n_2=-2%[/latex] [latex] n=n_1-n_2=3%[/latex] SSD = 200 m and [latex] h_1= 1.2 m[/latex] and [latex] h_2= 0.15 m[/latex] as given [latex] n_1[/latex] up gradient, and [latex] n_2[/latex] - down gradient. So curve is summit curve. Assume L > SSD [latex] \begin{aligned}
L &=\frac{NS^2}{2(\sqrt{n_1}+\sqrt{n_2})^2} \\ 
 &= \frac{3}{100} \times \frac{(200)^2}{2 \times (\sqrt{1.2}+\sqrt{0.15})^2}\\ 
 &=272.91>200 \\ 
 L&=272.91m 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: Given that, Traffic density = 40 Veh/Km. Time mean speed = 40 Kmph Space mean speed = 30 kmph Time Headway (sec) = ? We know that traffic volume = Density x Space mean speed = 40x30 =1200 Veh hr. and we also know that [latex]q=\frac{3600}{H_t} [/latex] where [latex]H_t[/latex]- average headway (sc) [latex]1200=\frac{3600}{H_t} [/latex] [latex]H_t=\frac{3600}{1200}=3 [/latex] secs.

solution:

question:
Question 41 For a traffic stream, [latex]v[/latex] is the space mean speed, [latex]k[/latex] is the density, [latex]q[/latex] is the flow,
[latex]v_f[/latex] is the free flow speed, and [latex]k_j[/latex] is the jam density. Assume that the speed
decreases linearly with density. Which of the following relation(s) is/are correct?
solution:
As per Greenshield's [latex]\begin{aligned}
 V&=V_f\left ( 1-\frac{K}{K_j} \right )\\
q&=K \times V \\
&= K \left [ 1-\frac{K}{K_j} \right ]V_f\\
q&=V_fK-\left ( \frac{V_f}{K_j} \right )K^2\\
V&=V_f\left [ 1-\frac{K}{K_j} \right ]
\end{aligned} [/latex] From above equation we can say that [latex] \begin{aligned}
 K&=K_j\left ( 1-\frac{V}{V_f} \right )\\
q&=K \times V \\
q&= K_j \left [ 1-\frac{V}{V_f} \right ] \times V\\
q&=K_jV-\left ( \frac{K_j}{V_f} \right )V^2

\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 The vehicle count obtained in every 10 minute interval of a traffic volume survey done in peak one hour is given below. [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline
 \text{Time Interval}&  \text{Vehicle Count}  \\ 
 \text{(in minutes)}&   \\ \hline
0-10& 10\\ \hline
10-20 &11\\ \hline
20-30&12\\ \hline
30-40&15\\ \hline
40-50 & 13\\ \hline
50-60 &11\\  \hline
\end{array}[/latex] The peak hour factor (PHF) for 10 minute sub-interval is __________.
(round off to one decimal place)
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
PHF&=\frac{\text{Peak flow during 1hour}}{6 \times \text{Peak flow during 10 minutes}}\\
&=\frac{10+11+12+15+13+11}{6 \times 15}\\
&=\frac{72}{6 \times 15}\\
&=0.8
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 44 At a traffic intersection, cars and buses arrive randomly according to independent
Poisson processes at an average rate of 4 vehicles per hour and 2 vehicles per
hour, respectively. The probability of observing at least 2 vehicles in 30 minutes
is ______. (round off to two decimal places)
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\lambda _C&=4 \; vehical/hr=2 \; vehical /30 \;min\\
\lambda _C&=2 \; vehical/hr=1 \; vehical /30 \;min\\
\lambda _{Vehical}&=3 \; vehical/30 \;min\\
P(x \lt  2)&=1-P(x\leq 1)\\
&=1-[P(x=0)+P(x=1)]\\
&=1-\left [ \frac{e^{-\lambda }\lambda ^0}{0!} +\frac{e^{-\lambda }\lambda ^1}{1!}\right ]\\
&=1-e^{-3}(1+3)\\
&=1-\frac{4}{e^3}\\
&=0.8
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 45 A two-phase signalized intersection is designed with a cycle time of 100 s. The
amber and red times for each phase are 4 s and 50 s, respectively. If the total
lost time per phase due to start-up and clearance is 2 s, the effective green time
of each phase is ______s. (in integer)
solution:
Two phase signalized intersections, Cycle time = 100 secs. Amber time = 4 secs. [each phase] Red time = 50 secs. [each phase] Total lost time = 2 sec. [each phase] Effective green time = ? [each phase] Total Effective green = Cycle time - Lost time
= 100-2x2 = 96 sec. As there is symmetry in phases so effective green
time per phase= 96/2=48 sec.

question: Question 48 For a [latex]2^{\circ} [/latex] curve on a high speed Broad Gauge (BG) rail section, the maximum sanctioned speed is 100 km/h and the equilibrium speed is 80 km/h. Consider dynamic gauge of BG rail as 1750 mm. The degree of curve is defined as the angle subtended at its center by a 30.5 m arc. The cant deficiency for the curve (in mm,round off to integer) is ________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Length of curve }&=\text { Radius } \times \text { Degree of curve }\\ \frac{30.5 \times 180}{2^{\circ} \times \pi}&=R\\ R &=873.76 \mathrm{~m} \\ C_{d} &=C_{t h}-C_{a c t} \\ C_{\mathrm{act}} &=\frac{G V^{2}}{127 R}=\frac{1750 \times 100^{2}}{127 \times 873.76}=157.70 \mathrm{~mm} \\ C_{\mathrm{ev}} &=\frac{G V^{2}}{127 R}=\frac{1750 \times 80^{2}}{127 \times 873.76}=100.930 \mathrm{~mm} \\ C_{\mathrm{def}} &=C_{\mathrm{act}}-C_{t h}=157.70-100.930=56.77 \mathrm{~mm} \\ &=57 \mathrm{~mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 The stopping sight distance (SSD) for a level highway is 140 m for the design speed of 90 km/h. The acceleration due to gravity and deceleration rate are [latex]9.81 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s^2}[/latex] and [latex]3.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s^2}[/latex], respectively. The perception/reaction time (in s,round off to two decimal places) used in the SSD calculation is ______________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{SSD} &=140 \mathrm{~m} \\ V &=90 \mathrm{kmph} \\ a &=3.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ \mathrm{SSD} &=V t_{R}+\frac{V^{2}}{2 g f} \\ a &=g f \\ 140 &=\left(\frac{5}{18} \times 90 \times t_{R}\right)+\frac{\left(\frac{5}{18} \times 90\right)^{2}}{2 \times 3.5} \\ t_{R} &=2.028 \mathrm{~seconds} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 In a three-phase signal system design for a four-leg intersection, the critical flow ratios for each phase are 0.18, 0.32, and 0.22. The total loss time in each of the phases is 2s. As per Webster's formula, the optimal cycle length (in s, round off to the nearest integer) is _______________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L &=2 \times 3=6 \text { seconds } \\ n &=3 \\ y &=(0.18+0.32+0.22) \\ C_{0} &=\left(\frac{1.5 L+5}{1-y}\right)=\left(\frac{1.5 \times 6+5}{1-(0.18+0.32+0.22)}\right) \\ &=50 \text { seconds } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 The longitudinal section of a runway provides the following data: [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|} \hline \text { End-to-end runway (m) } & \text { Gradient (\%) } \\ \hline 0 \text { to 300 } & +1.2 \\ \hline 300 \text { to } 600 & -0.7 \\ \hline 600 \text { to } 1100 & +0.6 \\ \hline 1100 \text { to } 1400 & -0.8 \\ \hline 1400 \text { to } 1700 & -1.0 \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex] The effective gradient of the runway (in %, round off to two decimal places) is _____________
solution: Assuming RL of start of runway as datum i.e., RL = 0 m) [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Effective gradient } &=\left[\frac{\text { Maximum difference in reduced level }}{\text { Total runway length }}\right] \\ &=\left[\frac{4.5-(-0.9)}{1700} \times 100\right] \% \\ &=0.3176 \% \simeq 0.32 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 55 Vehicular arrival at an isolated intersection follows the Poisson distribution. The mean vehicular arrival rate is 2 vehicle per minute. The probability (round off to two decimal places) that at least 2 vehicles will arrive in any given 1-minute interval is _____
solution: [latex]P(n,t)=\frac{(\lambda t)^n e^{-\lambda t}}{n!}[/latex] [latex]\lambda =2 \;v/m[/latex] [latex]t = 1 \text{ minute}[/latex] probability of at least 2 vehicles arriving in 1 ? minute is given by, [latex]1-(P(0,1)+P(1,1))[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &= 1-\left \{ \frac{(2 \times 1)^0 e^{-2(1)}}{0!}+\frac{(2 \times 1)^1 e^{-2(1)}}{1!} \right \}\\ &=1-\left \{ \frac{1(e^{-2})}{1}+ \frac{2(e^{-2})}{1} \right \} \\ &= 1-(e^{-2}+2e^{-2})\\ &=1-3e^{-2}=0.59 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 On a road, the speed - density relationship of a traffic stream is given by u=70 - 0.7k (where speed, u, is in km/h and density, k is in veh/km). At the capacity condition, the average time headway will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{u}&=70-0.07 \mathrm{k} \\ \mathrm{u}&=70\left[1-\frac{\mathrm{k}}{\frac{70}{0.7}}\right]\\ V_{f} &=70 \mathrm{kmph} \\ \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{j}} &=\frac{70}{0.7}=100 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{km} \\ \mathrm{q}_{\max } &=\frac{1}{4} V_{f} k_{j}=\left(\frac{1}{4} \times 70 \times 100\right)=1750 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{hr} \\ \mathrm{q}_{\max } &=\frac{3600}{h_{i}} \\ 1750 &=\frac{300}{h_{i}}\\ & \text{Average time headway}\\ h_{i}&=\frac{3600}{1750}=2.057=2.1 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 A signalized intersection operates in two phases. The lost time is 3 seconds per phase. The maximum ratios of approach flow to saturation flow for the two phases are 0.37 and 0.40. The optimum cycle length using the Webster's method (in seconds, round off to one decimal place) is ______________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{n} &=2, \mathrm{~L}=3 \times 2=6 \mathrm{sec} \\ \mathrm{y}_{1} &=0.37, \mathrm{y}_{2}=0.40 \\ \mathrm{Y} &=\mathrm{y}_{1}+\mathrm{y}_{2} \\ &=0.37+0.40 \\ &=0.77 \\ \mathrm{C}_{0} &=\left(\frac{1.5 \mathrm{~L}+5}{1-\mathrm{Y}}\right)=\frac{1.5 \times 6+5}{1-0.77} \\ &=60.87 \mathrm{sec} \simeq 60.9 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 60 The design speed of a two-lane two-way road is 60 km/h and the longitudinal coefficient
of friction is 0.36. The reaction time of a driver is 2.5 seconds. Consider acceleration
due to gravity as 9.8 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. The intermediate sight distance (in m, round off to the nearest
integer) required for the load is ________
solution: Given : f = 0.36; v = 60 km; g = 9.8 [latex]m/s^2;\; t_R=2.5s[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} SSD&= \left ( 0.278Vt_R+\frac{V^2}{254f} \right )\\ &= 0.278 \times 60 \times 2.5 +\frac{60^2}{254 \times 0.36}\\ &= 41.7+39.37=81m\\ ISD &=2 \times SSD\\ &=81 \times 2=162m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 61 For the hottest month of the year at the proposed airport site, the monthly mean of the
average daily temperature is 39[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]. The monthly mean of the maximum daily temperature
is 48[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] for the same month of the year. From the given information, the calculated Airport
Reference Temperature (in [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]), is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_a&=39^{\circ}C\\ T_m&=48^{\circ}C\\ ATR&=T_a+\left ( \frac{T_m-T_a}{3} \right )\\ &=39+\left ( \frac{48-39}{3}\right )\\&=42^{\circ}C \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 67 Traffic volume count has been collected on a 2 lane road section which needs upgradation
due to severe traffic flow condition. Maximum service flow rate per lane is observed as
1280 veh/h at level of service 'C'. The Peak Hour Factor is reported as 0.78125. Historical
traffic volume count provides Annual Average Daily Traffic as 122270 veh/day. Directional

of 'All Cars' and all drivers are 'Regular Commuters', the number of extra lane(s) (round
off to the next higher integer) to be provide, is ________.
solution: Number of the needed given LOS [latex]=\frac{DDHV}{PHF \times MSF \times F_{HV} \times f_p}[/latex] where, DDHV = Directional distribution hour volume PHF = Peak hour factor MSF = Maximum service flow rate of Los [latex]F_{HV}[/latex] = Heavy vehicle familiarity adjustment factor [latex]f_{p}[/latex] = Road under familiarity adjustment factor DDHV = 122270 x 0.6 = 7362 vah/day (0.6 - max. directional distributed) [latex]F_{HV}=f_p=1[/latex] as per given condition [latex]N=\frac{7362}{0.78125 \times 1280 \times 1 \times 1} =7.362 = 8 \text{ lanes}[/latex] Number of extra lanes [latex]= 8-2 = 6 \text{ lanes}[/latex]

question: Question 74 The speed-density relationship of a highway is given as u=100-0.5k where, u = speed in km per hour, k = density in vehicles per km. The maximum flow (in vehicles per hour, round off to the nearest integer) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} u&=100-0.5k\\ u&=100\left [ 1-\frac{k}{(100/0.5)} \right ]\\ \text{Green shield model}\;\;u&=V_f\left ( 1-\frac{k}{k_j} \right )\\ V_f&=\text{free mean speed}\\ &=100kmph\\ k_j&=\text{Jam density }\\ &=\frac{100}{0.5}=200 veh./km\\ \text{Max flow.}\;\;q_{max}&=\frac{1}{4}V_fk_j\\ &=\frac{1}{4} \times 100 \times 200=5000veh./hr \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 75 A broad gauge railway line passes through a horizontal curved section (radius = 875 m) of length 200 m. The allowable speed on this portion is 100 km/h. For calculating the cant, consider the gauge as centre-to-centre distance between the rail heads, equal to 1750 mm. The maximum permissible cant (in mm, round off to 1 decimal place) with respect to the centre-to-centre distance between the rail heads is_____
solution: For a railway track [latex]\begin{array}{l}\mathrm{Allowable}\;\mathrm{cant}=\frac{\mathrm G.\mathrm V^2}{127\mathrm R}\;\;\mathrm{where}\;\mathrm V\;\mathrm{is}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm{km}/\mathrm{hr}=100\\\mathrm{Allowable}\;\mathrm{cant}=\frac{1750\times100^2}{127\times895}=157.5\;\mathrm{mm}\end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 76 The uniform arrival and uniform service rates observed on an approach road to a signalized intersection are 20 and 50 vehicles/minute, respectively. For this signal, the red time is 30 s, the effective green time is 30 s, and the cycle length is 60 s. Assuming that initially there are no vehicles in the queue, the average delay per vehicle using the approach road during a cycle length(in s, round off to 2 decimal places) is ______
solution: Arrival rate = 20 veh/min Service rate = 50 veh/min R = 30 sec, [latex]G_i[/latex] = 30 sec, Cycle length = 60sec Time corresponding to which no. of arrival becomes same as no. of departure. [latex]\begin{aligned} 20 \times (R+t) &=50t \\ 20 \times (30+t)&=50t \\ t &=\frac{600}{30}=20sec \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Avg. Delay}&=\left ( \frac{\text{Area under arrival line}-\text{Area under departure line}}{\text{Cumulative number of vehicle arrival}} \right ) \\ &=\left ( \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times 16.67 \times 50 -\frac{1}{2} \times 16.67 \times 25}{20} \right )\\ &=12.50sec \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 A flexible pavement has the following class of loads during a particular hour of the day. i. 80 buses with 2-axles (each axle load of 40 kN); ii. 160 trucks with 2-axles (front and rear axle loads of 40 kN and 80 kN, respectively) The equivalent standard axle load repetitions for this vehicle combination as per IRC:37-2012 would be
solution: (i) 80 buses with 2 axle with 40 kN each. [latex]N_1=80 \times 2=160[/latex] [latex]L_1=40kN[/latex] [latex]160 \text{ truks} \left\{\begin{matrix} \text{Front axle}\rightarrow 40kN\\ \text{Rear axle}\rightarrow 80kN \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]N_1=160,\;L_1=40kN[/latex] [latex]N_2=160,\;L_2=80kN[/latex] [latex]\text{Total no. of repetitions}\left\{\begin{matrix} &\text{For}\; 40kN=160+160=320\\ &\text{For}\; 80kN=160 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]N_1=320,\;L_1=40kN[/latex] [latex]N_2=160,\;L_2=80kN[/latex] As per 4th power law [latex]\begin{aligned} N_s&=N_1\left ( \frac{L_1}{L_5} \right )^4 +N_2 \left ( \frac{L_2}{L_5} \right )^4 \\ &= 320\left ( \frac{40}{80} \right )^4+160\left ( \frac{80}{80} \right )^4\\ &= 20+160=180 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 78 A vehicle is moving on a road of grade +4% at a speed of 20 m/s. Consider the coefficient of rolling friction as 0.46 and acceleration due to gravity as 10 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. On applying brakes to reach a speed of 10 m/s, the required braking distance (in m, round off to nearest integer) along the horizontal, is ______
solution: Given, Upward gradient, G = 4% = 0.04 (upgrade is taken as +ve) Initial speed, [latex]v_1[/latex] = 20 m/s Coefficient of friction (rolling), f = 0.46 Acceleration due to gravity, g = 10 [latex]m/s^2[/latex] Final velocity due to break application (reduced), [latex]v_2[/latex] = 10 m/s Breaking distance, [latex]\begin{aligned} S_b&=\frac{(v_1^2-v_2^2)}{2g(f+G)} \\ &=\frac{(20^2-10^2)}{2 \times 10(0.46+0.04)} \\ &= 30m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 79 The speed-density relationship in a mid-block section of a highway follows the Greenshield's model. If the free flow speed is [latex]v_f[/latex] and the jam density is [latex]k_j[/latex], the maximum flow observed on this section is
solution: maximum flow [latex]=\frac{1}{4}v_fk_j[/latex]

Question 81 A parabolic vertical curve is being designed to join a road of grade +5% with a road of grade -3%. The length of the vertical curve is 400m measured along the horizontal. The vertical point of curvature (VPC) is located on the road of grade +5%. The difference in height between VPC and vertical point of intersection (VPI) (in m, round off to the nearest integer)is _____
solution: Given, [latex]N_1=+5\%,\; N_2=-3\%[/latex] Length of summit curve is, [latex]l = 400 m[/latex] Vertical distance between VPC and VPI is [latex]N_1 \times \frac{l}{2}=\frac{5\%}{100}\times 200=10m[/latex]

question: Question 82 Traffic on a highway is moving at a rate of 360 vehicles per hour at a location. If the number of vehicles arriving on this highway follows Poisson distribution, the probability (round off to 2 decimal places) that the headway between successive vehicles lies between 6 and 10 seconds is ______
solution: [latex]h_1=[/latex] 6 seconds, [latex]h_1=[/latex] 10 seconds given, avg. rate, [latex]\lambda =360\;veh/hr=360\times \frac{1}{3600}=\frac{1}{10}\; veh/sec[/latex] Probability that the headway is between [latex]h_1 \; and \; h_2[/latex] is given by, [latex]\begin{aligned} P(h_1\leq h\leq h_2)&=e^{\lambda h_1}-e^{-\lambda h_2} \\ &= e^{-\frac{1}{10}\times 6}-e^{-\frac{1}{10}\times 10}\\ &= 0.1808\approx 0.18 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 83 Average free flow speed and the jam density observed on a roadstretch are 60 km/h and 120 vehicles/km, respectively. For a linear speed-density relationship, the maximum flow on the road stretch (in vehicles/h) is _________
solution: Maximum Speed / Free ?ow speed, [latex]V_m[/latex] = 60 kmph Jam density, [latex]K_m[/latex] = 120 kmph for linear speed - density (Green shield's model) relationship, max. ?ow, is [latex]q_{max}=\frac{k_j}{2}\times \frac{V_f}{2}[/latex] [latex]q_{max}=\frac{120}{2}\times \frac{60}{2}=1800veh/hr[/latex]

question: Question 84 The maximum number of vehicles observed in any five minute period during the peak hour is 160. If the total flow in the peak hour is 1000 vehicles, the five minute peak hour factor (round off to 2 decimal places) is ___
solution: Given actual flow in peak hour, [latex]q_{actual}=10^3 \;\text{veh/hr}[/latex] peak 5 min rate = 160 veh/5min Peak (5min)rate volume, [latex]q_{\text{peak rate}}=\frac{160}{\frac{5}{60}} =1920\;\text{veh/hr}[/latex] Therefore, peak hourly factor (PHF) for 5 min is [latex]PHF_5=\frac{q_{\text{actual}}}{q_{\text{peak rate}}}=\frac{10^3}{1920}=0.52083\approx 0.52[/latex]

question: Question 85 The coefficient of average rolling friction of a road is [latex]f_r[/latex] and its grade is +G%. If the grade of this road is doubled, what will be the percentage change in the braking distance (for the design vehicle to come to a stop) measured along the horizontal (assume all other parameters are kept unchanged)?
solution: Percentage change in Braking Distance [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\left ( \frac{L_{B_1}-L_{B_2} }{L_{B_1}} \right ) \times 100\\ \%\Delta L_B&=\frac{\frac{V^2}{254[f_r+0.01G]}-\frac{V^2}{254[f_r+0.02G]}}{\frac{V^2}{254[f_r+0.01G]}}\\ &=\frac{f_r+0.02G-f_r-0.01G}{(f_r+0.01G)(f_r+0.02G)} \times (f_r+0.01G)\\ \%\Delta L_B&=\left ( \frac{0.01G}{f_r+0.02G} \times 100 \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 A 7.5 m wide two-lane road on a plain terrain is to be laid along a horizontal curve of radius 510 m. For a design speed of 100 kmph, super-elevation is provided as per IRC: 73-1980. Consider acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]. The level difference between the inner and outer edges of the road (in m, up to three decimal places) is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} e &=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{225 R}=\frac{100^{2}}{225 \times 510} \\ &=0.0871 \times 0.07=\tan \theta \\ \sin \theta & \simeq 0.07 \\ x &=7.5 \times \sin \theta=0.525 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 The space mean speed (kmph) and density (vehicles/km) of a traffic stream are linearly related. The free flow speed and jam density are 80 kmph and 100 vehicles/km respectively. The traffic flow (in vehicles/h, up to one decimal place) corresponding to a speed of 40 kmph is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} V_{t}=\text { Free mean speed }=50 \mathrm{kmph} \\ k_{j}=\text { Jam density }=100 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{km} \end{array}[/latex] As per linear model (green-shield) [latex] V=V_{f}\left(1-\frac{k}{k_{j}}\right)[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Density @ speed =40 kmph [latex] 40 =80\left(1-\frac{k}{100}\right)=50 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{km}[/latex] Traffic flow @ density 50 veh/km @ speed [latex] 40 \mathrm{kmph} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} q=V k \\ q=V_{f}\left(k-\frac{k^{2}}{k_{j}}\right)\\ \Rightarrow \quad 80\left(50-\frac{50^{2}}{100}\right)=2000 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{hr} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 88 A car follows a slow moving truck (travelling at a speed of 10 m/s) on a two-lane two-way highway. The car reduces its speed to 10 m/s and follows the truck maintaining a distance of 16 m from the truck. On finding a clear gap in the opposing traffic stream, the car accelerates at an average rate of 4 m/[latex]s^2[/latex], overtakes the truck and returns to its original lane. When it returns to its original lane, the distance between the car and the truck is 16 m. The total distance covered by the car during this period (from the time it leaves its lane and subsequently returns to its lane after overtaking) is
solution: Overtaking time, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad T=\sqrt{\frac{4 S}{a}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \times 16}{4}}=4 \mathrm{sec} \\ S=\text { Space heady way }=16 \mathrm{m} \\ a=\text { Acceleration }=4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{array}[/latex] Distance travelled by vehicle [latex]=S_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{2} &=u T+\frac{1}{2} a T^{2} \\ &=10 \times 4+\frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 4^{2}=72 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 92 Given the following data: design life n = 15 years, lane distribution factor D = 0.75, annual rate of growth of commercial vehicles r = 6%, vehicle damage factor F = 4 and initial traffic in the year of completion of construction = 3000 Commercial Vehicles Per Day (CVPD). As per IRC:37-2012, the design traffic in terms of cumulative number of standard axles (in million standard axles, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_{s}=& \frac{365 A\left[\left(1+\frac{r}{100}\right)^{n}-1\right] \times V D F \times L D F}{\frac{r}{100}} \\ =& \frac{365 \times 3000\left[1.06^{15}-1\right] \times 4 \times 0.75}{0.06} \times 10^{-6}\\ &76.45\text{msa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 93 A priority intersection has a single-lane one-way traffic road crossing an undivided two-lane two-way traffic road. The traffic stream speed on the single-lane road is 20 kmph and the speed on the two-lane road is 50 kmph. The perception-reaction time is 2.5s, coefficient of longitudinal friction is 0.38 and acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]. A clear sight triangle has to be ensured at this intersection. The minimum lengths of the sides of the sight triangle along the two-lane road and the single-lane road, respectively will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{SSD}_{2} &=0.278 \times V t_{R}+\frac{V^{2}}{254 f} \\ &=0.278 \times 50 \times 2.5+\frac{50^{2}}{254 \times 0.38} \simeq 61 \mathrm{m} \\ \mathrm{SSD}_{1} &=0.278 \times 20 \times 2.5+\frac{20^{2}}{254 \times 0.38} \simeq 18 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] As per data given and based on calculation of SSD the answer would be 61 m and 18 m. But, as per the code IRC : 66 of sight distance calculation at priority intersection, the sight triangle at priority intersection should be formed by measuring a distance of 15 m along minor road and a distance equal to 8 seconds travel at the design speed [latex](50 \times 0.278 \times 8 \simeq 111 m) [/latex] along major road. Hence answer will be 111 m and 15 m.

question: Question 97 The radii of relative stiffness of the rigid pavements P and Q are denoted by [latex]l_{P}[/latex] and [latex]l_{Q}[/latex], respectively. The geometric and material properties of the concrete slab and underlying soil are given below: The ratio (up to one decimal place) of [latex]l_{P} / l_{Q}[/latex] is _______
solution: Relative stiffness, [latex] \begin{aligned} l &=\left[\frac{E h^{3}}{12 k\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)}\right]^{1 / 4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{l_{P}}{l_{Q}} &=\frac{\left(h^{3} / k\right)^{1 / 4}}{\left[\frac{(0.5 h)^{3}}{2 k}\right]^{1 / 4}}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 Two cars P and Q are moving in a racing track continuously for two hour. Assume that no other vehicles are using the track during this time. The expressions relating the distance travelled d (in km) and time t (in hour) for both the vehicles are given as P: [latex]d=60t[/latex] Q: [latex]d=60t^{2}[/latex] Within the first one hour, the maximum space headway would be
solution: Space headway, [latex] \begin{aligned} S &=60 t-60 t^{2} \\ \frac{d S}{d t} &=60-120 t=0 \\ t &=0.5 \mathrm{hr}=30 \text { minutes } \\ \frac{d^{2} S}{d t^{2}} &=-120 \times 0 \text { (Maxima) } \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Maximum space head, [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{\max } &=60 \times 0.5-60 \times(0.5)^{2} \\ &=15 \mathrm{km} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 99 While aligning a hill road with a ruling gradient of 6 %, a horizontal curve of radius 50 m is encountered. The grade compensation (in percentage, up to two decimal places) to be provided for this case would be _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{G} . \mathrm{C} .&= \text{ Minimum of }\left(\frac{75}{R}\right. or \left.\frac{30+R}{R}\right) \\ & = \text{Minimum of }\left(\frac{75}{50}\right. or \left.\frac{30+50}{50}\right) \\ &= \text{Minimum of }(1.5\text{ or }1.6 ) \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Grade compensation [latex]=1.5 \%[/latex]

question: Question 101 For a broad gauge railway track on a horizontal curve of radius R (in m), the equilibrium cant e required for a train moving at a speed of V (in km per hour) is
solution: [latex]\theta(\text { in } \mathrm{cm})=\frac{G V^{2}}{127 R}=\frac{1.676 \mathrm{V}^{2}}{127 \mathrm{R}} \times 100=1.315 \frac{\mathrm{V}^{2}}{\mathrm{R}}[/latex]

question: Question 102 The radius of a horizontal circular curve on a highway is 120 m. The design speed is 60 km/hour, and the design coefficient of lateral friction between the tyre and the road surface is 0.15. The estimated value of superelevation required (if full lateral friction is assumed to develop), and the value of coefficient of friction needed (if no superelevation is provided) will, respectively, be
solution: Given, [latex]R=120 \mathrm{m}, V=60 \mathrm{kmph}\text{ and }f=0.15 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad e+f&=\frac{v^{2}}{127 R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e+0.15&=\frac{60^{2}}{127 \times 120} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e&=\frac{1}{11.6} \\ \text{Also, if }e&=0\\ \Rightarrow \quad f&=\frac{V^{2}}{127 R}=\frac{60^{2}}{127 \times 120} \simeq 0.24 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 103 The queue length (in number of vehicles) versus time (in seconds) plot for an approach to a signalized intersection with the cycle length of 96 seconds is shown in the figure. At time t = 0, the light has just turned red. The effective green time is 36 seconds, during which vehicles discharge at the saturation flow rate, s (in vph). Vehicles arrive at a uniform rate, v (in vph), throughout the cycle. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution:
Vehicle arrived upto 60 sec (Red time) = 10 Arrival rate [latex]= 1060 \times 3600=600 \; vph[/latex] [latex]v=600\; vph[/latex] Departure at vehicle starts at 60 second and ends 90 seconds. So, between 60 second to 90 second total vehicle departed

= Vehicle arrived upto 60 second + Vehicle arriving between 60 sec to 90 sec [latex]= 10 + 6003600 \times 30[/latex] [latex]
= 10 + 5= 15[/latex] So, departure rate = Saturation flow [latex]
= s = 1530 \times 3600[/latex] [latex]s=1800\; vph[/latex] Average delay time is given by [latex]t_d=\frac{\frac{C}{2}\left ( 1-\frac{g}{c} \right )^2}{1-\frac{v}{s}}[/latex] C = 96 second g = 96 -60 = 36 seconds v = 600 Vph s = 1800 Vph [latex]t_d=\frac{\frac{96}{2}\left ( 1-\frac{36}{96} \right )^2}{1-\frac{600}{1800}}[/latex] [latex]t_d=28.125 \; sec[/latex]

options.A: v = 600 vph, and for this cycle, the average stopped delay per vehicle = 30 seconds
options.B: s = 1800 vph, and for this cycle, the average stopped delay per vehicle = 28.125 seconds
options.C: v = 600 vph, and for this cycle, the average stopped delay per vehicle = 45 seconds
options.D: s = 1200 vph, and for this cycle, the average stopped delay per vehicle = 28.125 seconds

question: Question 104 The following observations are made while testing aggregate for its suitability in pavement construction: i. Mass of oven-dry aggregate in air = 1000 g ii. Mass of saturated surface-dry aggregate in air = 1025 g iii. Mass of saturated surface-dry aggregate under water = 625 g Based on the above observations, the correct statement is
solution: Bulk specific gravity [latex]=\frac{A}{B-C} [/latex] Apparent specific gravity [latex]=\frac{A}{A-C} [/latex] Where, A= Mass of oven dry aggregate in air B= Mass of Saturated surface dry aggregate in air C= Mass of Saturated surface dry aggregate under water [latex] \therefore[/latex] Bulk specific gravity [latex] =\frac{1000}{1025-625}=\frac{1000}{400}=2.5[/latex] Water absorption [latex] =\frac{1025-1000}{1000} \times 100=2.5 \%[/latex]

options.A: bulk specific gravity of aggregate = 2.5 and water absorption = 2.5 %
options.B: bulk specific gravity of aggregate = 2.5 and water absorption = 2.4 %
options.C: apparent specific gravity of aggregate = 2.5 and water absorption = 2.5%
options.D: apparent specific gravity of aggregate = 2.5 and water absorption = 2.4 %

question: Question 105 Vehicles arriving at an intersection from one of the approach road follow the Poisson distribution. The mean rate of arrival is 900 vehicles per hour. If a gap is defined as the time difference between two successive vehicle arrivals (with vehicles assumed to be points), the probability (up to four decimal places) that the gap is greater than 8 seconds is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \lambda &=900\text{veh/hour}\\ &=\frac{900}{3600}=\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{sec} \\ P[t \geq 8 \mathrm{sec}] &=\theta^{-\lambda t} \\ &=e^{-\frac{1}{4} \times 8}=e^{-2}=0.1353 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 A runway is being constructed in a new airport as per the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) recommendations. The elevation and the airport reference temperature of this airport are 535 m above the mean sea level and 22.65[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C, respectively. Consider the effective gradient of runway as 1%. The length of runway required for a design-aircraft under the standard conditions is 2000 m. Within the framework of applying sequential corrections as per the ICAO recommendations, the length of runway corrected for the temperature is
solution: Elevation =535 m Airport Reference Temperature [latex]=22.65^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] Effective Gradient = 1% Runway length =2000 m under standard conditions. Runway length correction for [latex]T^{\circ} \mathrm{C} .[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex]Correction for elevation [latex] =\frac{7}{100} \times 2000 \times \frac{535}{300}=249.67 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Corrected runway length [latex]=2249.67 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Corrected standard [latex]T^{\circ}[/latex] at 535 m elevation [latex] =15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}-(0.0065 \times 535)=11.52^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] Correction for [latex]T^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{100} \times 2249.67 \times \frac{\Delta T^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}{1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}} \\ \Delta T^{\circ} \mathrm{C} &=22.65-11.52=11.13^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ &=\frac{1}{100} \times 2249.67 \times \frac{11.13^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}{1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}} \\ &=250.39 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Corrected Runway length [latex] \begin{array}{l} =2249.67+250.39 \\ =2500.06 \mathrm{m} \simeq 2500 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 107 A super-elevation e is provided on a circular horizontal curve such that a vehicle can be stopped on the curve without sliding. Assuming a design speed v and maximum coefficient of side friction [latex]f_{max}[/latex], which one of the following criteria should be satisfied?

options.C: no limit on e can be set

question: Question 108 A motorist travelling at 100 km/h on a highway needs to take the next exit, which has a speed limit of 50 km/h. The section of the roadway before the ramp entry has a downgrade of 3% and coefficient of friction (f) is 0.35. In order to enter the ramp at the maximum allowable speed limit, the braking distance (expressed in m) from the exit ramp is________
solution: Total energy lost between point (1) and (2) = Work done by frictional force [latex] \frac{1}{2} m v_{1}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m v_{2}^{2}+m g \times 0.03 s=f \times(m g) \times s [/latex] [latex] \frac{(0.278 \times 100)^{2}}{2}-\frac{(0.278 \times 50)^{2}}{2}+9.81 \times 0.03 \times s [/latex] [latex] =0.35 \times 9.81 \times s [/latex] [latex] 289.815=3.1392 \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad s=92.32 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 109 The critical flow ratios for a three-phase signal are found to be 0.30, 0.25, and 0.25. The total time lost in the cycle is 10 s. Pedestrian crossings at this junction are not significant. The respective Green times (expressed in seconds and rounded off to the nearest integer) for the three phases are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y &=y_{1}+y_{2}+y_{3} \\ &=0.30+0.25+0.25 \\ &=0.80 \end{aligned}[/latex] NowTotal lost time, L=10 sec (given) [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] Optimum cycle time. [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{0} &=\frac{1.5 L+5}{1-Y} \\ C_{0} &=\frac{(1.5 \times 10)+5}{1-0.80}=\frac{15+5}{0.20}=\frac{20}{0.2} \\ &=100 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now green times are calculated by, [latex] \begin{aligned} G_{1} &=\frac{y_{1}}{y}\left(C_{0}-L\right)=\frac{0.30}{0.80}(100-10) \\ &=33.75 \simeq 34 \mathrm{sec} \\ G_{2} &=\frac{y_{2}}{y}\left(C_{0}-L\right)=\frac{0.25}{0.80}(100-10) \\ &=28.11 \simeq 28 \mathrm{sec} \\ G_{3} &=\frac{y_{3}}{y}\left(C_{0}-L\right)=\frac{0.25}{0.80}(100-10) \\ &=28.11 \simeq 28 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 110 If the total number of commercial vehicles per day ranges from 3000 to 6000, the minimum percentage of commercial traffic to be surveyed for axle load is

Question 111 In the context of the IRC 58-2011 guidelines for rigid pavement design, consider the following pair of statements. I: Radius of relative stiffness is directly related to modulus of elasticity of concrete and inversely related to Poisson's ratio II: Radius of relative stiffness is directly related to thickness of slab and modulus of subgrade reaction. Which one of the following combinations is correct?
solution:
Radius of relative stiffness, [latex]
l=\left[\frac{E h^{3}}{12 k\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)}\right]^{1 / 4}[/latex] As [latex]\mu[/latex] increases then [latex]1-\mu^{2}[/latex] decreases [latex]
 \therefore \quad [/latex] Relative stiffness also increases. [latex]
 \therefore [/latex] Statement I is false. Modulus of subgrade reaction, [latex]
k=\frac{P}{\Delta}[/latex] Statement II is false.

question: Question 112 While traveling along and against the traffic stream, a moving observer measured the relative flows as 50 vehicles/hr and 200 vehicles/hr, respectively. The average speeds of the moving observer while traveling along and against the stream are 20 km/hr and 30 km/hr, respectively. The density of the traffic stream (expressed in vehicles/km) is _______.
solution: Let us assume, q= traffic flow k= traffic density [latex] V_{w}=[/latex] velocity of test vehicle along the stream [latex] V_{\mathrm{a}}=[/latex] velocity of test vehicle against the stream [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad q-k V_{w}&=50 \\ \Rightarrow q-k \times 20&=50 &\ldots(i)\\ q+k V_{a}&=200 \\ \Rightarrow q+k \times 30&=200 &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex] k=3Veh/km[/latex]

question: Question 113 A two lane, one-way road with radius of 50 m is predominantly carrying lorries with wheelbase of 5 m. The speed of lorries is restricted to be between 60 kmph and 80 kmph. The mechanical widening and psychological widening required at 60 kmph are designated as [latex]w_{me\,,60}[/latex] and [latex]w_{ps\,,60}[/latex] respectively. The mechanical widening and psychological widening required at 80 kmph are designated as [latex]w_{me\,,80}[/latex] and [latex]w_{ps\,,80}[/latex] and and respectively. The correct values of [latex]w_{me\,,60},\: w_{ps\,,60},\: w_{me\,,80},\: w_{ps\,,80}[/latex] respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{m e^{\prime} 60}&=\frac{n^{2}}{2 R}=\frac{2 \times 5^{2}}{2 \times 50}=0.5 \mathrm{m} \\ W_{\rho s^{\prime} 60}&=\frac{V}{9.5 \sqrt{R}}=\frac{60}{9.5 \sqrt{60}}=0.89 \mathrm{m} \\ W_{\operatorname{me}^{\prime} 80}&=\frac{n^{2}}{2 R}=\frac{2 \times 5^{2}}{2 \times 50}=0.5 \mathrm{m} \\ W_{\mathrm{ps}^{\prime} 80}&=\frac{V}{9.5 \sqrt{R}}=\frac{80}{9.5 \sqrt{50}}=1.19 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 114 In a one-lane one-way homogeneous traffic stream, the observed average headway is 3.0 sec. The flow (expressed in vehicles/hr) in this traffic stream is __________.
solution: Given: Average headway [latex] =3.0 \mathrm{sec}[/latex] Flow of traffic stream [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{1}{\text { headway }} \\ =\left(\frac{1}{\frac{3}{60 \times 60}}\right) \text { veh/hr } \\ =1200 \text { veh/hr } \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 116 In Marshall method of mix design, the coarse aggregate, fine aggregate, fines and bitumen having respective values of specific gravity 2.60, 2.70, 2.65 and 1.01, are mixed in the relative proportions (% by weight) of 55.0, 35.8, 3.7 and 5.5 respectively. The theoretical specific gravity of the mix and the effective specific gravity of the aggregates in the mix respectively are:
solution: Theoretical specific gravity, [latex] \begin{aligned} G_{t} &=\frac{w_{1}+w_{2}+w_{3}+w_{4}}{\frac{w_{1}}{G_{1}}+\frac{W_{2}}{G_{2}}+\frac{W_{3}}{G_{3}}+\frac{W_{4}}{G_{b}}} \\ &=\frac{55+35.8+3.7+5.5}{\frac{55}{2.6}+\frac{35.8}{2.7}+\frac{3.7}{2.65}+\frac{5.5}{1.01}}+ \\ &=2.42 \end{aligned}[/latex] Effective specific gravity of aggregates (coarse + fine) is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} G^{\prime} &=\frac{(55 \times 2.6)+(35.8 \times 2.7)}{55+35.8} \\ &=2.639=2.64 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 Match the information related to test on aggregates given in Group-I with that in Group-II.
Question 118 The relation between speed u (in km/h) and density k (number of vehicles/km) for a traffic stream on a road is u=70-0.7k. The capacity on this road is _________vph (vehicles/hour).
solution: Traffic volume, [latex] \begin{aligned} q &=u k \\ q &=(70-0.7 k) k \\ &=70 k-0.7 k^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum possible volume is capacity of road For maximum volume, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d q}{d k}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 70-1.4 k&=0\\ \Rightarrow \quad k&=50 \mathrm{Veh} / \mathrm{km} \\ \text{Now, capacity,}\\ C&=(70-0.7 \times 50) \times 50 \\ C&=1750 \mathrm{Veh} / \mathrm{hr} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 119 The following statements are made related to the lengths of turning lanes at signalized intersections: (i) 1.5 times the average number of vehicles (by vehicle type) that would store in turning lane per cycle during the peak hour. (ii) 2 times the average number of vehicles (by vehicle type) that would store in turning lane per cycle during the peak hour. (iii) Average number of vehicles (by vehicle type) that would store in the adjacent through lane per cycle during the peak hour. (iv) Average number of vehicles (by vehicle type) that would store in all lanes per cycle during the peak hour. As per the IRC recommendations, the correct choice for design length of storage lanes is
solution:
Design length is the average of (i) and (iii) as per 
Indian Roads Congress (IRC) recommendations 
for storage lanes

question: Question 120 A superspeedway in New Delhi has among the highest super-elevation rates of any track on the Indian Grand Prix circuit. The track requires drivers to negotiate turns with a radius of 335 m and 33[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] banking. Given this information, the coefficient of side friction required in order to allow a vehicle to travel at 320 km/h along the curve is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R &=335 \mathrm{m} \\ V &=320 \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr} \\ e+f &=\frac{V^{2}}{127 R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad f &=\frac{V^{2}}{127 R}-e\\ &=\frac{320^{2}}{127 \times 335}-\tan 33^{\circ} \\ &=1.761 \end{aligned}[/latex] Note: While deriving the above equation, we consider '[latex]1-e f \simeq 1[/latex]' but this is not valid in this case because banking provided is very high [latex] \left(\tan 33^{\circ}=0.65\right).[/latex] So formula used should be [latex] \frac{e+f}{1-e f}=\frac{V^{2}}{127 R} [/latex] which will result in f=0.685

question: Question 121 A sign is required to be put up asking drivers to slow down to 30 km/h before entering zone Y (see figure). On this road, vehicles require 174 m to slow down to 30 kmn/h (the distance of 174 m includes the distance travelled during the perception reaction time of drivers). The sign can be read by 6/6 vision drivers from a distance of 48 m. The sign is placed at a distance of x m from the start of Zone Y so that even a 6/9 vision drive can slow down to 30 km/h before entering the zone. The minimum value of x is _______ m.
solution:
For a driver having 6/6 vision can see the board 
from distance 48m. For a driver having 6 / 9 vision can see the board 
from distance [latex]48 \times \frac{6}{9}=32 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Vehicle requires 174 \mathrm{m} to slow down to 30 km / hr. So minimum distance of X from the start of Y zone 
 =174-32=142m

question: Question 122 On a circular curve, the rate of superelevation is e. While negotiating the curve a vehicle comes to a stop. It is seen that the stopped vehicle does not slide inwards (in the radial direction). The coefficient of side friction is f. Which of the following is true :
solution: For equilibrium, [latex] \begin{aligned} f N & \geq m g \sin \theta \\ \Rightarrow\quad f m g \cos \theta & \geq m g \sin \theta \\ \Rightarrow\quad f \cos \theta & \geq \sin \theta \\ \Rightarrow\quad f & \geq \tan \theta \\ \Rightarrow\quad f & \geq e \\ \text{or}\quad e & \leq f \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 The acceleration time relationship for a vehicle subjected to non-uniform acceleration is, [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d}v }{\mathrm{d} t}=(\alpha -\beta v_{0})e^{-\beta t}[/latex] Where, v is the speed in m/s, t is the time in s, [latex]\alpha[/latex] and [latex]\beta[/latex] are parameters, and [latex]v_{0}[/latex] is the initial speed in m/s. If the accelerating behavior of a vehicle, whose drive intends to overtake a slow moving vehicle ahead, is described as, [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t}=(\alpha -\beta v)[/latex] considering [latex]\alpha =2 m/s^{2}[/latex], [latex]\beta =0.05s^{-1}[/latex] and [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d}v }{\mathrm{d} t}=1.3 m/s^{2}[/latex] at t=3s, the distance(in m) travelled by the vehicle in 35s is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\frac{d v}{d t}=\alpha-\beta v\\ &\Rightarrow \quad \int \frac{d v}{(\alpha-\beta v)}=\int d t\\ &\Rightarrow \quad \frac{\ln (\alpha-\beta v)}{-\beta}=t+C\\ &\text { at } t=3 \text { sec, } \frac{d v}{d t}=\alpha-\beta v=1.3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\\ &\Rightarrow \frac{\ln (1.3)}{-0.05}=3+c \Rightarrow c=-8.247\\ &\therefore \quad \ln (2-0.05 \times v)=(t-8.247)(-0.05)\\ &\Rightarrow 2-0.05 \times v=1.51 \mathrm{e}^{-0.05 t}\\ &\Rightarrow v=\frac{d s}{d t}=40-30.21 e^{-0.05 t}\\ &\Rightarrow s=40 t+604.15 e^{-0.05 t}+c^{\prime}\\ &\therefore \quad \text { at } t=0, s=0 \Rightarrow c^{\prime}=-604.15\\ &\Rightarrow \quad s=40 t+604.15 e^{-0.05 t}-604.15\\ &\text { at } t=35 \mathrm{sec}\\ &\Rightarrow \quad s=40 \times 35+604.15 \mathrm{e}^{-0.05 \times 35}-604\\ &\Rightarrow \quad s=900.84 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 124 Which of the following statements CANNOT be used to describe free flow speed ([latex]u_{f}[/latex]) of a traffic stream?
solution: Free flow speed [latex](V_{f})[/latex] is that speed at which flow and density is negligible

options.A: [latex]u_{f}[/latex] is the speed when flow is negligible
options.B: [latex]u_{f}[/latex] is the speed when density is negligible
options.C: [latex]u_{f}[/latex]  is affected by geometry and surface conditions of the road
options.D: [latex]u_{f}[/latex]  is the speed at which flow is maximum and density is optimum

question: Question 125 The penetration value of a bitumen sample tested at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is 80. When this sample is heated to 60[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and tested again, the needle of the penetration test apparatus penetrates the bitumen sample by d mm. The value of d CANNOT be less than _____mm.
solution: Relationship between penetration and temperature is given by, [latex] \begin{array}{l} P=A T+K \\ P=\text { Penetration }\\ A= \text{Temperature susceptibility }\\ K= \text{Constant }\\ \end{array}[/latex] With increase in temperature, penetration increases. Hence, we will simply take, [latex] d \nless \frac{80}{10}=8 \mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question: Question 126 A pre-timed four phase signal has critical lane flow rate for the first three phases as 200, 187 and 210 veh/hr with saturation flow rate of 1800 veh/hr/lane for all phases. The lost time is given as 4 seconds for each phase. If the cycle length is 60 seconds, the effective green time (in seconds) of the fourth phase is _________
solution: Flow rates for the first three phase are given as [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{1}&=200 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{hr} \\ q_{2}&=187 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{hr}\\ \text{and}\quad q_{3}&=210 \text { veh/hr } \end{aligned}[/latex] Saturation flow rate is 1800 veh/hr/lane Lost time, [latex] L=4 \times 4=16 \mathrm{sec}[/latex] Length of the cycle, [latex] C_{0}=60 \mathrm{sec}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Now, } \quad y_{1} &=\frac{q_{1}}{s_{1}}=\frac{200}{1800} \\ y_{2} &=\frac{q_{2}}{s_{2}}=\frac{187}{1800} \\ y_{3} &=\frac{q_{3}}{s_{3}}=\frac{210}{1800} \\ C_{0} &=\frac{1.5 L+5}{1-y} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 60 &=\frac{1.5 \times 16+5}{1-y}\\ \Rightarrow 60 &=\frac{24+5}{1-y} \\ \Rightarrow 1-y &=\frac{29}{60} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y&=\frac{1-29}{60}=\frac{60-29}{60} \\ &=0.517\\ \text{And}\quad y&=y_{1}+y_{2}+y_{3}+y_{4}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.517 &=\frac{597}{1800}+y_{4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{4}&=0.185 \\ G &=\frac{y_{4}}{y}\left(C_{0}-L\right)\\ &=\frac{0.185}{0.517}(60-16) \\ &=15.745 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 On a section of a highway the speed-density relationship is linear and is given by [latex]v=[80-\frac{2}{3}k][/latex]; where v is in km/h and k is in veh/km. The capacity (in veh/h) of this section of the highway would be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v&=80-\frac{2 k}{3} \\ \text{Capacity,}\quad &=v \times k \\ &=80 k-\frac{2 k^{2}}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] For q to be maximum [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d q}{d k}&=0\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d q}{d k} &=80-\frac{4 k}{3}=0 \\ \Rightarrow k&=60 \end{aligned} [/latex] Maximum capacity, [latex] \begin{aligned} q&=80 \times 60-\frac{2}{3}(60)^{2} \\ &=4800-\frac{2}{3} \times 3600 \\ &=2400 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 128 A student riding a bicycle on a 5 km one-way street takes 40 minutes to reach home. The student stopped for minutes during this ride. 60 vehicles overtook the student (assume the number of vehicles overtaken by the student is zero) during the ride and 45 vehicles while the student stopped. The speed of vehicle stream on that road (in km/hr) is
solution: Velocity of student [latex]=\frac{5 k m}{(40-15) \min } [/latex] [latex] =12\mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr}[/latex] [latex] \left(\frac{\text { Vehicle/min }}{\text { Relative speed of vehicle w.r.t. student }}\right)_{\text {moving}} [/latex] [latex] =\left(\frac{\text { Vehicle/min }}{\text { Relative speed of vehicle w.r.t. student }}\right)_{\text {standing }} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \frac{60 / 25}{x-12} &=\frac{45 / 15}{x-0} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x &=60 \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 129 In a Marshall sample, the bulk specific gravity of mix and aggregates are 2.324 and 2.546 respectively. The sample includes 5% of bitumen (by total weight of mix) of specific gravity 1.10. The theoretical maximum specific gravity of mix is 2.441. The void filled with bitumen (VFB) in the Marshall sample (in %) is _______
solution: [latex]V_{v}=\frac{G_{t}-G_{m}}{G_{t}} \times 100=\frac{2.441-2.324}{2.441} \times 100[/latex] [latex] =4.79 \% [/latex] Void filled with bitumen, [latex] \begin{array}{l} V_{b}=G_{m} \times \frac{W_{b}(\%)}{G_{b}}=2.324 \times \frac{5}{1.1}=10.56 \%\\ \mathrm{VMA}=V_{v}+V_{b}=4.79+10.56=15.35 \% \\ \therefore \mathrm{VFB}=\frac{V_{b}(\%)}{\mathrm{VMA}} \times 100=\frac{10.56}{15.35} \times 100=68.79 \% \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 130 An observer counts 240 veh/h at a specific highway location. Assume that the vehicle arrival at the location is Poisson distributed, the probability of having one vehicle arriving over a 30 seconds time interval is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P(n, t)&=\frac{e^{-\lambda t} \cdot(\lambda t)^{n}}{n !} \\ \text{Here,}\quad \lambda&= no. of vehicles\\ &=240 \text{vehicle}/\mathrm{km} \\ P(1,30) &=\frac{e^{\frac{-240 \times 30}{3600}}\left(\frac{240}{3600} \times 30\right)^{1}}{1 !} \\ &=2 . e^{-2}=0.2707 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 131 A road is being designed for a speed of 110 km/hr on a horizontal curve with a super elevation of 8%. If the coefficient of side friction is 0.10, the minimum radius of
the curve (in m) required for safe vehicular movement is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} e+f &=\frac{(0.278 \mathrm{V})^{2}}{\mathrm{g} R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e+f &=\frac{V^{2}}{127 R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad R &=\frac{V^{2}}{127(e+f)} \\ &=\frac{(110)^{2}}{127(0.08+0.1)} \\ &=528.5 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 132 The average spacing between vehicles in a traffic stream is 50 m, then the density (in veh/km) of the stream is_______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Capacity } &=\frac{1000 \times V}{S}=V \times \text { density } \\ \Rightarrow \quad \text { Density }&=\frac{1000}{S}=20 \text { veh } / \mathrm{km} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 133 An isolated three-phase traffic signal is designed by Webster's method. The critical flow ratios for three phases are 0.20, 0.30, and 0.25 respectively, and lost time per phase is 4 seconds. The optimum cycle length (in seconds) is ___________
solution: Sum of the flow, [latex] \begin{aligned} y &=y_{1}+y_{2}+y_{3} \\ &=0.2+0.3+0.25=0.75 \end{aligned}[/latex] Total lost time in a cycle [latex]L=4 \times 3=12\text{ sec}. [/latex] Optimum cycle length, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{0} &=\frac{1.5 L+5}{1-y} \\ \frac{1.5 \times 12+5}{1-0.75} &=92 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 134 The speed-density (u-k) relationship on a single lane road with unidirectional flow u= 70-0.7k, where u is in km/hr and k is in veh/km. The capacity of the road (in veh/hr) is________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Capacity } &=\text { Velocity } \times \text { Density } \\ \Rightarrow \quad C &=V \times K \\ &=70 K-0.7 K^{2} \\ \text { Now, } \quad \frac{d C}{d K} &=70-1.4 K=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K &=50\\ \Rightarrow \quad \text { Capacity, } &=70 \times 50-0.7(50)^{2} \\ &=1750 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{hr} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 135 The perception-reaction time for a vehicle travelling at 90 km/h, given the coefficient of longitudinal friction of 0.35 and the stopping sight distance of 170 m (assume g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex] ), is _____________ seconds.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{SSD}&=0.278 \mathrm{vt}_{r}+\frac{(0.278 \mathrm{v})^{2}}{2 \mathrm{gf}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 170&=0.278 \times 90 \times t_{r}+\frac{(0.278 \times 90)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.35} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad t_{r}&=3.1510 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 136 A traffic survey conducted on a road yields an average daily traffic count of 5000 vehicles. The axle load distribution on the same road is given in the following table: The design period of the road is 15 years, the yearly traffic growth rate is 7.5% and the load safety factor(LSF)1.3. If the vehicle damage factor (VDF) is calculated from the above data, the design traffic (in million standard axle load, MSA) is ____________
solution: Vehicle damage factor [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.1\left[\frac{18}{8.2}\right]^{4}+0.2\left[\frac{14}{8.2}\right]^{4}+0.35\left[\frac{10}{8.2}\right]^{4} \\ &\quad+0.15\left[\frac{8}{8.2}\right]^{4}+0.20\left[\frac{6}{8.2}\right]^{4} \\ N_{s}&=\frac{365 A\left((1+r)^{n}-1\right) D F}{r} \\ &=\frac{365 \times 5000\left((1.075)^{15}-1\right) \times 1.3 \times 4.988}{0.075} \\ N_{s}&=309.08 \mathrm{msa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 The following statements are related to temperature stresses developed in concrete pavement slabs with free edges (without any restraint): P. The temperature stresses will be zero during both day and night times if the pavement slab is considered weightless Q. The temperature stresses will be compressive at the bottom of the slab during night time if the self-weight of the pavement slab is considered R. The temperature stresses will be compressive at the bottom of the slab during day time if the self -weight of the pavement slab is considered The TRUE statement(s) is(are)
solution: The temperature stress will be tensile at the bottom of the slab during the day time if the self weight of the pavement slab is considered.

question: Question 138 The minimum value of 15 minute peak hour factor on a section of a road is
solution:
15 min. peak hr factor is used for traffic 
intersection design, [latex]
\begin{array}{c}
\mathrm{PHF}=\frac{(\mathrm{V} / 4)}{V_{15}} \\
V=\text { Peak hourly volume }\left(\mathrm{in} \frac{\mathrm{veh} .}{\mathrm{hr} .}\right)
\end{array}[/latex] [latex]
 V_{15}=[/latex] Maximum 15 minute volume within the peak 
hr. (veh.) Maximum value is 1.0 and minimum value is 0.25 Normal range is 0.7-0.98

question:
Question 139 For a portion of national highway where a descending gradient of 1 in 25 meets with an ascending gradient
of 1 in 20, a valley curve needs to be designed for a vehicle travelling at 90 kmphbased on the following
conditions. (i) headlight sight distance equal to the stopping sight distance (SSD) of a level terrain considering length of valley curve [latex]\gt[/latex] SSD. (ii) comfort condition with allowablerate of change of centrifugal acceleration = 0.5 m/[latex]sec^3[/latex]. Assume total reaction time = 2.5 seconds; coefficient of longitudinal friction of the pavement= 0.35; height
of head light of the vehicle =0.75 m; andbeam angle = 1[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. What is the length of valley curve (in m) based on the comfort condition? __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{v} &=2\left[\frac{N V^{3}}{C}\right]^{1 / 2} \\ &=2\left[\frac{0.09 \times(0.278 \times 90)^{3}}{0.5}\right]^{v 2} \\ &=106.066 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 143 It was observed that 150 vehicles crossed a particular location of a highway ina duration of 30
minutes. Assuming that vehicle arrival follows a negative exponential distribution, find out the
number of time headways greater than 5 seconds in the above observation? __________
solution: [latex]P(x)=\frac{\lambda^{n} e^{-\lambda}}{x !}[/latex] Where, P(x) is the probability of x events (vehicle arrivals) in some time interval (t). [latex] \lambda [/latex] is the mean arrival rate in that interval. [latex] \lambda=\frac{150}{30 \times 60} \times 5=\frac{5}{12}[/latex] Now, the probability that zero vehicle arrive in an interval t, denoted as P(0), will be same as the probability that the headway (into arrival time) greater than or equal to t. [latex] \begin{array}{l} \therefore P(x=0)=\frac{\lambda^{0} e^{-\lambda}}{0 !}=e^{-5 / 12}=0.6592 \\ \therefore P(x=0)=0.6592 \end{array}[/latex] Number of time headway in 30 minutes [latex] \begin{array}{l} =0.6592 \times 30 \times 60 \\ =1186.63 \end{array}[/latex]
