Question 145 A two-lane urban road with one-way traffic has a maximum capacity of 1800 vehicles/hour. Under
the jam condition, the average length occupied by the vehicles is 5.0 m. The speed versus density
relationship is linear. For a traffic volume of 1000 vehicles/hour, the density (in vehicles/km) is
solution: Capacity per lane [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{1800}{2}=900 \text { Vehicle/hour } \\ k_{j} &=\frac{1000}{5}=200 \text { Veh. } / \mathrm{km} \\ q_{\max } &=\frac{V_{s t} \times k_{j}}{4} \\ 900 &=\frac{V_{s t} \times 200}{4}\\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{s t}&=18 \mathrm{kmph} \\ \therefore \quad V&=V_{s f}\left[1-\frac{k}{k_{j}}\right] \\ \therefore \quad q&=v k \\ \because \quad q&=V k \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Since traffice volume =1000 vehicle/hour for two lane So, for single lane, [latex] \begin{aligned} q&=500 \text{ vehicle/hour } \\ q&=V_{s f}\left[1-\frac{k}{k_{l}}\right] k \\ \Rightarrow \quad 500&=18\left[1-\frac{k}{200}\right] k \\ \Rightarrow \quad 27.77&=k-\frac{k^{2}}{200} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 5554&=200 k-k^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad k^{2}-200 k&+5554=0 \\ \therefore \quad k=33.32 &\text{Veh./km (for single lane)}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] So, for two lane urban road, [latex] k=33.32 \times 2=66.64=67[/latex]

question:
Question 146 The following data are related to a horizontal curved portion of a two-lane highway: length of
curve = 200 m, radius of curve = 300 m and width of pavement = 7.5 m. In order to provide a
stopping sight distance (SSD) of 80 m, the set back distance (in m) required from the centre line of
the inner lane of the pavement is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{ccc} \text{Length of curve,} &L_{c}&=200 \mathrm{m} \\ \text{ Radius,}&R&=300 \mathrm{m}\\ \text{Width,}&w&=7.5 \mathrm{m}\\ \text{SSD, }&S&=80 \mathrm{m} \\ \because \quad L_{c} \gt S&& \end{array}[/latex] Set back distance, [latex] \begin{aligned} m &=(R)-(R-d) \cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \\ \frac{\alpha}{2} &=\frac{180 \cdot S}{2 \pi(R-d)}=\frac{180 \times 80}{2 \pi \times\left(300-\frac{7.5}{4}\right)} \\ &=7.687 \\ m &=300-\left(300-\frac{7.5}{4}\right) \cos (7.687) \\ &=4.53 \end{aligned}[/latex] After this: The setback distance (in m) required from the centre line of the inner lane of the pavement is [latex]= 4.55-\frac{7.5}{4} = 2.675 m[/latex]

Question 147 A pavement designer has arrived at a design traffic of 100 million standard axles for a newly
developing national highway as per IRC:37 guidelines using the following data: design life =
15 years, commercial vehicle count before pavement construction = 4500 vehicles/day, annual
traffic growth rate = 8%. The vehicle damage factor used in the calculation was
solution: Number of commercial vehicles per day, [latex] A=4500[/latex] Annual traffic growth rate, [latex] r=8 \%[/latex] Design life, n=15 years The cumulative standard axles, [latex] N_{s}=100 \times 10^{6}[/latex] Vehicle damage factor used [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{N_{s} \times r}{365 A\left[(1+r)^{n}-1\right]} \\ &=\frac{100 \times 10^{6} \times 0.08}{365 \times 4500 \times\left[(1+0.08)^{15}-1\right]} \\ &=2.24 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 151 The cumulative arrival and departure curve of one cycle of an approach lane of
a signalized intersection is shown in the figure. The cycle time is 50 s
and the effective red time is 30 s and the effective green time is 20 s. What is the
average delay?
solution: Average delay [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\left(\begin{array}{c}\text { Area of triangle formed } \\ \text { by arrival curve }\end{array}\right)-\left(\begin{array}{c}\text { Area of triangle formed } \\ \text { by departure curve }\end{array}\right)}{\text { No. of vehicles }} \\ &=\frac{\frac{1}{2} \times 40 \times 50-\frac{1}{2} \times 40 \times 20}{40} \\ &=15 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 156 The probability that k number of vehicles arrive (i.e. cross a predefined line) in
time t is given as [latex](\lambda t)^k e^{-\lambda t}/K!, \; where \; \lambda[/latex] is the average vehicle arrival rate. What is the probability that the time headway is greater than or equal to time [latex]t_{1}[/latex]?
solution: Probability of arriving 'n' number of vehicles in time t [latex] P(n)=\frac{(\lambda t)^{n} e^{-\lambda t}}{n !}[/latex] If time headway is greater than or equal to time t, then number of vehicles arrive is zero, [latex] \Rightarrow \quad P(0) \frac{\left(\lambda t_{1}\right)^{o} e^{-\lambda t_{1}}}{o !}=e^{-\lambda t_{1}}[/latex]

Question 158 The design speed for a two-lane road is 80 km/h. When a design vehicle with a
wheelbase of 6.6 m is negotiating a horizontal curve on that road, the off-tracking
is measured as 0.096 m. The required widening of carriageway of the two-lane
road on the curve is approximately
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Off-tracking, } \frac{l^{2}}{2 R} &=0.096 \mathrm{m} \\ \Rightarrow\quad R &=\frac{(6.6)^{2}}{2 \times 0.096}=226.875 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Extra widening, } E_{w} &=n \times \frac{l^{2}}{2 R}+\frac{V}{9.5 \sqrt{R}} \\ &=2 \times 0.096+\frac{80}{9.5 \sqrt{226.875}} \\ &=0.192+0.56=0.752 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 159 Consider the following statements in the context of geometric design of roads. I : A simple parabolic curve is an acceptable shape for summit curves II : Comfort to passengers is an important consideration in the design of
summit curves. The correct otption evaluating the above statements and their relationship is
solution:
When fast moving vehicle travels along a summit 
curve the centrifugal force will act upwards 
against gravity and hence a part of the pressure 
on the tyres and spring of the vehicle suspensions 
is relieved. So there is no problem of discomfort 
to passengers on Summit curves. The only 
problem is designing summit curves is to provide 
adequate sight distances. Circular summit curve is ideal curve as the sight 
distance available throughout the length of circular >
curve is constant. The deviation angles in vertical 
curves of highways are very small and so between 
the same tangent points, a simple parabola is 
nearly congruent with a circular arc; also a 
parabola is very easy for arithmetical manipulation 
for computing ordinates. Thus, in actual practice 
a simple parabolic curve is used as a summit 
curve instead of the circular arc.

options.A: I is true, II is false
options.B: I is true, II is true, and II is the correct reason for I
options.C: I is true, II is true, and II is NOT the correct reason for I
options.D: I is false, II is true

Question 163 On a specific highway, the speed-density relationship follows the Greenbeg's model [latex][v=v_{f}ln(k_{j}/k)][/latex], where [latex]v_{f}[/latex] and [latex]k_{j}[/latex] are the free flew speed and jam density respectively. When the highway is operating at capacity, the density obtained as
per this model is
solution: Given, [latex]\quad v=v_{f} \log _{e}\left(\frac{k_{j}}{k}\right) [/latex] But Capacity, [latex] \begin{aligned} C &=\text { traffic density } \times \text { speed } \\ &=k \times v \\ \Rightarrow \quad C &=v_{t} k \log _{e}\left(\frac{k_{I}}{k}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] For maximum capacity, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{d C}{d k}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad v_{f} \times \frac{d}{d k}\left[k \log _{\theta}\left(\frac{k_{1}}{k}\right)\right]=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad k \frac{d}{d k} \log _{\theta}\left(\frac{k_{1}}{k}\right)+\log _{e}\left(\frac{k_{j}}{k}\right) \frac{d}{d k} k=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad k \times \frac{k}{k_{j}} \times k_{l} \times\left(-\frac{1}{k^{2}}\right)+\log _{e} \frac{k_{j}}{k}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \log _{e} \frac{k_{j}}{k}=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad e=\frac{k_{j}}{k} \\ \Rightarrow \quad k=\frac{k_{j}}{e} \end{array}[/latex]

Question 168 A horizontal curvature curve with a centre line radius of 200 m is provided on a 2-lane, 2-way SH section. The width of the 2-lane road is 7.0 m. Design speed for this section is 80 km per hour. The brake reaction time is 2.4 s, and the
coefficients of friction in longitudinal and lateral directions are 0.355 and 0.15,
respectively. The set-back distance from the centre line of the inner lane is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m &=(R-d)-(R-d) \cos \frac{\alpha}{2} \\ \frac{\alpha}{2} &=\frac{180 S}{2 \pi(R-d)} \\ &=\frac{180 \times 125}{2 \times \pi\left(200-\frac{7}{4}\right)}=18.063 \\ \therefore \quad m &=200-\left(200-\frac{7}{4}\right) \cos (18.063) \\ &=11.52 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, set back distance from centre line of inner lane [latex] =11.52-\left(\frac{7}{4}\right)=9.77 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

Question 169 A horizontal curvature curve with a centre line radius of 200 m is provided on a 2-lane, 2-way SH section. The width of the 2-lane road is 7.0 m. Design speed for this section is 80 km per hour. The brake reaction time is 2.4 s, and the
coefficients of friction in longitudinal and lateral directions are 0.355 and 0.15,
respectively. The safe stopping sight distance on the section is
solution: Safe stopping sight distance [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.278 \mathrm{Vt}+\frac{v^{2}}{254 \mathrm{f}} \\ &=(0.278 \times 80 \times 2.4)+\frac{(80)^{2}}{254 \times 0.355} \\ &=124.35 \mathrm{m} \approx 125 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 170 A linear relationship is observed between speed and density on a certain section
of a highway. The free flow speed is observed to be 80 km per hour and the
jam density is estimated as 100 vehicles per km length. Based on the above
relationship, the maximum flow expected on this section and the speed at the
maximum flow will respectively be
solution: The maximum flow may be calculated as, [latex] q_{\max }=\frac{\text { free flow speed } \times \text { jam density }}{4}[/latex] [latex] =\frac{80 \times 100}{4}=2000 [/latex] vehicles per hour Maximum flow occurs when the speed becomes half of the free flow speed i.e. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Speed at } q_{\max } &=\frac{\text { free flow speed }}{2} \\ &=\frac{80}{2}=40 \mathrm{km} \text { per hour } \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: 8000 vehicles per hour and 80 km per hour
options.B: 8000 vehicles per hour and 25 km per hour
options.C: 2000 vehicles per hour and 80 km per hour
options.D: 2000 vehicles per hour and 40 km per hour

Question 171 It is proposed to widen and strength and existing 2-lane NH section as a divided
highway. The existing traffic in one direction is 2500 commercial vehicles (CV)
per day. The construction will take 1 year. The design CBR of soil subgrade is
found to be 5 percent. Given : traffic growth rate for CV = 8 percent, vehicle
damage factor =3.5 (standard axles per CV), design life = 10 years and traffic
distribution factor =0.75. The cumulative standard axles (msa) computed are
solution: Number of commercial vehicles per day, A = existing traffic [latex]\times [/latex] traffic distribution factor [latex] =2500 \times(1.08) \times 0.75=2025 [/latex] Annual growth rate of commercial vehicles =8 % Vehicle damage factor, F=3.5 Design life, n=10 years, Thus, the cumulative standard axles (msa) may be calculated as [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{S}=& \frac{365 A\left[(1+r)^{n}-1\right]}{r} \times F \\ &=\frac{365 \times 2025 \times\left[\left(1+\frac{8}{100}\right)^{10}-1\right]}{\frac{8}{100} \times 3.5} \\ =& 37.47 \approx 37 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 173 A roundabout is provided with an average entry width of 8.4 m, width of weaving
section as 14 m, and length of the weaving section between channelizing islands
as 35 m. The crossing traffic and total on the weaving section are 1000 and 2000
PCU per hour respectively. The nearest rounded capacity of the roundabout (in
PCU per hour) is
solution: Width of the weaving section, W = 14 m Average entry width, e = 8.4 m Length of weaving section between channelizing islands, L =35 m Proportion of weaving traffic is_given by, [latex] p =\frac{\text{crossing traffic on the weaving section}}{\text{total traffic on the weaving section}}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad P = \frac{1000}{2000}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad p=0.5 [/latex] The capacity of the roundabout may be given as, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q=& \frac{280 w\left(1+\frac{e}{w}\right)\left(1-\frac{p}{3}\right)}{1+\frac{w}{L}} \\ Q=& \frac{280 \times 14 \times\left(1+\frac{8.4}{14}\right) \times\left(1-\frac{0.5}{3}\right)}{1+\frac{14}{35}} \\ =& 3733.33 \approx 3700 \mathrm{PCU} \text { per hour } \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 179 The following data pertains of the number of commercial vehicles per day for the
design of a flexible pavement for a national highway as per IRC:37-1984 : Assuming a traffic growth factor of 7.5% per annum for both the types of vehicles, the cumulative number of standard axle load repetitions (in million) for a design life of ten years is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_{9} &=\frac{365 A_{1}\left[(1+r)^{n}-1\right]}{r} \times F_{1} \\ &=\frac{365 \times 2000\left[\left(1+\frac{7.5}{100}\right)^{10}-1\right]}{\left(\frac{7.5}{100}\right) \times 10^{6}} \times 5 \\ &=51.6 \mathrm{msa} \\ N_{s 2} &=\frac{365 A_{2}\left[(1+r)^{n}-1\right]}{r} \times F_{2}\\ &= \frac{365 \times 200\left[\left(1+\frac{7.5}{100}\right)^{10}-1\right]}{\left(\frac{7.5}{100}\right) \times 10^{6}} \times 6 \\ &= 6.2 \\ N_{s}&= N_{9}+N_{s_{2}}=51.6+6.2 \\ &= 57.8 \mathrm{msa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 180 The width of the expansion join is 20 mm in a cement concrete pavement. The paying temperature is [latex]20^{\circ}C[/latex] and the maximum slab temperature in summer is [latex]60^{\circ}C[/latex]. The coefficient of the thermal expansion of concrete is [latex]10\times 10^{-6} mm/mm/^{\circ}C[/latex] and the joint filler compresses up to 50% of the thickness. The spacing between expansion joints should be
solution: The spacing of expansion joint is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} L_{e} &=\frac{\delta^{\prime}}{100 C\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right)} \\ \text { Given } \delta &=\frac{\text { Width of expansion joint }}{2} \\ &=\frac{20}{2}=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ L_{e} &=\frac{1}{100 \times 10 \times 10^{-6}(60-20)}=25 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 181 The design speed on a road is 60 kmph. Assuming the driver reaction time of
2.5 seconds and coefficient of friction of pavement surface as 0.35, the required
stopping distance for two-way traffic on a single lane road is

 \frac{30+R}{R}\text{ or }\frac{75}{R}[/latex] whichever is minimum [latex]

\text{or }\frac{75}{50}&=1.5 \\

ratios of normal flows to saturation flow of two directional traffic is 0.50 and the

Question 188 At an horizontal curve portion of a 4 lane undivided carriageway, a transition
curve is to be introduced to attain required superelevation.
The design speed is 60 kmph and radius of the curve is 245 m. Assume length of
wheel base of a longest vehicle as 6 m, superelevation rate at 5% and the rate of introduction of this superelevation as 1 in 150. The length of
the transition curve (m) required, if the pavement is rotated about inner edge is
solution: [latex]L_{s}=\frac{v^{3}}{C R} \dots[/latex] according to allowable rate of centrifugal acceleration, [latex] \begin{aligned} L_{s}&=\frac{(0.278 \times 60)^{3}}{0.59 \times 6245}=32.10 \mathrm{m}\\ C&=\frac{80}{V+75} \quad\text{(V is in kmph) }\\ \text{and}\quad L_{s}&=110.2 \mathrm{m}\\ &\dots\text{ according to superelevation}\\ L_{s}&=39.7 \mathrm{m}\\ &\dots\text{according to IRC formula }\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum of above three will be the length of transition curve [latex] L_{s}=110.2 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:
Question 189 On an urban road, the free mean speed was measured as 70 kmph and the average
spacing between the vehicles under jam condition as 7.0 m. The speed-flow-density
equation is given by : [latex]U=U_{sf}[1-\frac{k}{k_{j}}][/latex] and q=Uk Where,
U = space-mean speed (kmph); k= density (veh/km); [latex]U_{sf}[/latex] = free mean speed (kmph);
[latex]k_j[/latex] = jam density (veh/km); q = flow (veh/hr). The maximum flow (veh/hr) per lane for this condition is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Traffic volume }&=\text { Density } \times \text { Speed } \\ q&=U k \\ \Rightarrow \quad q&=U_{s t}\left(1-\frac{k}{k_{j}}\right) k \\ \Rightarrow \quad q&=U_{s f}\left(k-\frac{k^{2}}{k_{j}}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] Jam density, [latex] \begin{aligned} k_{j}&=\frac{1000}{\text { average spacing between vehicles }} \\ k_{j}&=\frac{1000}{7} \text { and } U_{s t}=70 \mathrm{kmph} \end{aligned}[/latex] For maximum traffic volume,[latex] \frac{d q}{d k}=0[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad U_{s f}\left(1-\frac{2 k}{k_{j}}\right)&=0 &\left[\because U_{sf}\neq 0 \right ]\\ \Rightarrow \quad 1-\frac{2 k}{k_{j}}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad k&=\frac{k_{j}}{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] Maximum traffic volume, [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{\max }&=U_{s f}\left(\frac{k_{j}}{2}-\frac{\left(k_{j} / 2\right)^{2}}{k_{j}}\right) \\ &=U_{s t}\left(\frac{k_{j}}{2}-\frac{k_{j}}{4}\right)=U_{s t}\left(\frac{k_{j}}{4}\right) \\ &=70 \times \frac{1000}{7 \times 4}=2500 veh/hr \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 190 For designing a 2-phase fixed type signal at an intersection having North-South
and East-West road where only straight ahead traffic is permitted, the following
data is available. Total time lost per cycle is 12 seconds. The cycle lenght (second) as per webster's approach is
solution: For N-S road and E-W road the higher traffic volume will be taken i.e. [latex] \begin{aligned} q_{1} &=1000 \text { and } q_{2}=900 \\ S_{1} &=2500 \text { and } S_{2}=3000 \\ y_{1} &=\frac{q_{1}}{S_{1}}=\frac{1000}{2500}=0: 4\\ \text{and }\quad y_{2}&=\frac{q_{2}}{S_{2}}=\frac{900}{3000}=0.3 \\ \therefore\quad Y&=y_{1}+y_{2}=0.4+0.3=0.7 \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Optimum cycle time, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{0} &=\frac{1.5 L+5}{1-Y}=\frac{1.5 \times 12+5}{1-0.7} \\ &=76.67 \approx 77 \mathrm{seconds} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 191 A vehicle moving at 60 kmph on an ascending gradient of a highway has to come
to stop position to avoid collision with a stationary object. The ratio of lag to
brake distance is 6:5. Considering total reaction time of the driver as 2.5 seconds
and the coefficient of longitudinal friction as 0.36, the value of ascending gradient(%) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Lag distance } &=0.278 \mathrm{Vt} \\ &=0.278 \times 60 \times 2.5 \\ &=41.7 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Brake distance }&=\frac{5}{6} \times 41.7=34.75 \mathrm{m} \\ &\left[\because \frac{\text { Lag distance }}{\text { Braking distance }}=\frac{6}{5}\right] \\ \text { Braking distance } &=\frac{V^{2}}{254(f+0.01 n)}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 34.75&=\frac{(60)^{2}}{254(0.36+0.01 n)} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.01 n&=\frac{(60)^{2}}{254 \times 34.75}-0.36 \\ \Rightarrow \quad n&=4.8 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 192 A subgrade soil sample was tested using standard CBR apparatus and the
observations are given below. Assuming that the load-penetration curve is convex throughout, the CBR value(%) of the sample is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{CBR}_{2.5}&=\frac{\begin{array}{c}\text { Load sustained by }\\\text { specimend at 2.5 mm penetration} \end{array}}{\begin{array}{c}\text { Load sustained by standard }\\\text{aggregates at 2.5mm penetration} \end{array}} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{60.5}{1370} \times 100=4.4 \%\\ \text{Also} \\ \text{CBR}_{5.0}&=\frac{\begin{array}{c}\text { Load sustained by }\\\text { specimend at 5.0 mm penetration} \end{array}}{\begin{array}{c}\text { Load sustained by standard }\\\text{aggregates at 5 mm penetration} \end{array}} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{80.5}{2055} \times 100=3.9 \%\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, the higher value of CBR which is obtained at 2.5 mm penetration is adopted i.e. 4.4%.

Question 198 A single lane unidirectional highway has a design speed of 65 kmph. The
perception-brake-reaction time of drivers is 2.5 seconds and the average length of
vehicles is 5 m. The coefficient of longitudinal friction of the pavement is 0.4. The
capacity of this road in term of vehicles per hour per lane is
solution: Space headway, [latex] \begin{aligned} S &=0.278 \mathrm{V} t+\frac{V^{2}}{254 \mathrm{f}}+L \\ &=0.278 \times 65 \times 2.5+\frac{(65)^{2}}{254 \times 0.4}+5 \\ &=91.8 \mathrm{m}\\ \text{Capacity,}\\ C &=\frac{1000 \mathrm{V}}{S}=\frac{1000 \times 65}{91.8} \\ &=708.37 \approx 710 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 200 For a 25 cm thick cement concrete pavement, analysis of stresses gives the following values : Wheel load stress due to corner loading : 30 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] Wheel load stress due to edge loading : 32 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] Warping stress at corner region during summer : 9 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] Warping stress at corner region during winter : 7 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] Warping stress at edge region during summer : 8 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] Warping stress at edge region during summer : 6 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] Frictional stress during summer : 5 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] Frictional stress during winter : 4 kg/c[latex]m^{2}[/latex] The most critical stress value for this pavement is
solution:
There are four cases which should be considered: (i) - During summer, critical combination of stresses 
at edges =wheel load stress due to edge loading +warping stress at edge region during summer - frictional stress during summer [latex]
= 32 + 8 - 5 = 35\text{ kg/cm}^{2}[/latex] (ii) During winter, critical combination of stresses 
at edges. =wheel load stress due to edge loading +warping stress at edge region during winter + frictional stress during winter [latex]
=32 + 6 + 4 = 42 \text{kg/cm}^{2}[/latex] (iii) During summer, critical combination of stresses 
at corner regions =wheel load stress at cor,ner loading + warping stress at corner region during summer [latex]
=30 +9=39 \text{kg/cm}^{2}[/latex] (iv) During winter, critical combination of stresses 
at corner region =wheel load stress at corner loading + Warping stress at corner region during winter [latex]
 =30+7=37 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} [/latex] Hence, the critical combination is [latex]
 42 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} [/latex]

question: Question 206 The data given below pertain to the design of a flexible pavement : Initial traffic = 1213 cvpd Traffic growth rate = 8% per annum Design life = 12 years Vehicle damage factor = 2.5 Distribution factor = 1.0 The design traffic in terms of million standard axles (msa) to be catered would be
solution: The cumulative number of standard axle load, [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{s} &=\frac{365 A\left[(1+r)^{n}-1\right]}{r} \times F \\ &=\frac{365 \times 1213 \times\left[\left(1+\frac{8}{100}\right)^{12}-1\right]}{8 / 100} \times 2.5 \times 10^{-6} \\ &=21.00 \mathrm{msa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 207 A Marshall specimen is prepared for bituminous concrete with a bitumen content
of 5 percent by weight of total mix. The theoretical and the measured unit weight of mix are 2.442 [latex]g/cm^{3}[/latex] and 2.345 [latex]g/cm^{3}[/latex], respectively. The bitumen has a specific gravity of 1.02. The percent voids in mineral aggregate filled with bitumen (VFB) are
solution: Percentage air voids, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{v} &=\left[\frac{G_{t}-G_{m}}{G_{t}}\right] \times 100 \\ &=\frac{2.442-2.345}{2.442} \times 100=3.97 \% \end{aligned}[/latex] Void filled with bitumen, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{b} &=G_{m} \times \frac{W_{b}}{G_{b}}=2.345 \times \frac{5}{1.02} \\ &=11.5 \% \\ \mathrm{VMA} &=V_{v}+V_{b}=3.97+11.5=15.461 \% \\ \therefore \quad \mathrm{VFB} &=\frac{V_{b} \%}{\mathrm{VMA} \%} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{11.5 \%}{15.47 \%} \times 100 \% \\ &=74.33 \%=74.3 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 214 The plate load test conducted with a 75 cm diameter plat on soil subgrade yielded
a deflection of 2.5 mm under a stress of 800 [latex]N/cm^{2}[/latex]. The modulus of elasticity of the subgrade soil, in [latex]kN/cm^{2}[/latex] is

Question 219 Temperature stresses in concrete pavements may cause the slab to crack. If a slab
cools uniformly then the crack will develop at the which of the following locations
of the slab ?
solution:
The corners and edges are free to contract while 
cooling. Hence, the cracks due to stresses will 
develop at the centre of the slab.

question: Question 226 The radius of relatives stiffness for a 20 cm thick slab with [latex]E = 3 \times 10^{5} kg/cm^{2}[/latex] and poisson's ratio = 0.15, resting on a subgrade having modulus of 5 kg/[latex]cm^{3}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Given, } h=20 \mathrm{cm}, E=3 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\ \mu=0.15, k=5 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ \qquad \begin{aligned} L &=\left[\frac{E h^{3}}{12 k\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)}\right]^{1 / 4} \\ &=\left[\frac{3 \times 10^{5} \times 20^{3}}{12 \times 5\left[1-(0.15)^{2}\right]}\right]^{1 / 4}\\ &79.98cm\approx80cm \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 227 A valley curve has a descending gradient of 1 in 40 followed by an ascending gradient of 1 in 50. The length of the valley curve required for a design speed of 80 km/hour for comfort condition is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L &=2\left[\frac{N v^{3}}{C}\right]^{1 / 2} \\ &=0.38\left[N V^{8}\right]^{1 / 2} \quad\left[\text { since } C=0.6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{3}\right] \\ N &=\frac{1}{40}-\left(+\frac{1}{50}\right)=\frac{1}{40}+\frac{1}{50}=0.045 \\ \therefore \quad L &=0.38\left[0.045 \times 80^{3}\right]^{1 / 2} \\ &=57.67 \mathrm{m} \simeq 58 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]
